data.text: Architecturally, the school embodies Catholic characteristics. Perched atop the Main Building's gold dome stands a golden statue of the Virgin Mary. Directly facing it at the front of the Main Building is a copper depiction of Christ with arms raised, accompanied by the inscription "Venite Ad Me Omnes." Adjacent to the Main Building lies the Basilica of the Sacred Heart, and directly behind it is the Grotto, a Marian site for prayer and reflection. This grotto mirrors the one at Lourdes, France, where the Virgin Mary is believed to have appeared to Saint Bernadette Soubirous in 1858. At the terminus of the main drive—aligned with three statues and the Gold Dome—is a modest, contemporary stone statue of Mary.

data.text: Similar to many universities, Notre Dame's student body operates several news media outlets. These nine student-managed platforms include three newspapers, a radio station, a television station, and various magazines and journals. The Scholastic magazine, which began as a one-page journal in September 1876, is published bi-monthly and claims to be the oldest ongoing collegiate publication in the United States. Another magazine, The Juggler, is released semiannually and showcases student literature and artwork. An annual yearbook, The Dome, is also available. The newspapers cover different topics; for example, The Observer, which publishes daily with a focus on university and other news, includes students from both Notre Dame and Saint Mary's College as contributors. Unlike Scholastic and The Dome, The Observer operates independently without faculty oversight or editorial guidance from the University. In 1987, in response to perceived conservative bias at The Observer, a liberal newspaper called Common Sense was introduced. Conversely, when a liberal bias was perceived in 2003, the conservative publication Irish Rover commenced production. Although neither of these newspapers is published as frequently as The Observer, all three are distributed campus-wide. Additionally, in Spring 2008, an undergraduate political science research journal titled Beyond Politics debuted.

data.text: The university serves as a primary base for the Congregation of Holy Cross, although its official headquarters are in Rome. Located across St. Joseph Lake from the Main Building is the main seminary, Moreau Seminary. Old College, near the shore of St. Mary Lake and the oldest structure on campus, accommodates undergraduate seminarians. Retired priests and brothers reside at Fatima House (a former retreat center), Holy Cross House, and Columba Hall near the Grotto. The university maintains connections with theologian Frederick Buechner through Moreau Seminary. Although not Catholic, Buechner has commended writers from Notre Dame, leading to the creation of the Buechner Prize for Preaching by Moreau Seminary.

data.text: Founded in 1920, the College of Engineering originally included civil and mechanical engineering courses under the College of Science from the 1870s. It is currently located within Fitzpatrick, Cushing, and Stinson-Remick Halls of Engineering and comprises five departments: aerospace and mechanical engineering, chemical and biomolecular engineering, civil engineering and geological sciences, computer science and engineering, and electrical engineering, offering eight B.S. degrees. Additionally, the college provides five-year dual degree programs in collaboration with the Colleges of Arts and Letters and of Business, granting additional B.A. and Master of Business Administration (MBA) degrees, respectively.

The U.S. News & World Report has previously acknowledged this program as outstanding.

data.text: In 1854-1855, the university initially introduced graduate degrees with a Master of Arts (MA) program. Subsequently, it expanded to include a Master of Laws (LL.M.) and a Master of Civil Engineering during its early expansion phase, prior to establishing formal graduate school requirements without mandatory theses for degree completion. In 1924, specific criteria were established for graduate programs, including the introduction of Doctorate (PhD) degrees. Currently, each of the five colleges provides graduate education. Numerous departments within the College of Arts and Letters offer PhD programs, alongside a professional Master of Divinity (M.Div.) program. Every department in the College of Science offers PhD programs except for Pre-Professional Studies. The School of Architecture presents a Master of Architecture degree, while all engineering departments provide PhD programs. The College of Business delivers various professional programs, such as MBA and Master of Science in Accountancy, with operations extending to Chicago and Cincinnati for its executive MBA program. Additionally, the Alliance for Catholic Education offers a Master of Education program that includes summer studies at the university and two years of teaching at Catholic schools across the Southern United States.

data.text: Notre Dame is renowned for its selective admissions process; in fall 2015, it accepted 3,577 students from a pool of 18,156 applicants (19.7%). The academic caliber of the enrolled class consistently ranks among the top 10 to 15 nationally for research universities. The institution offers a non-restrictive early action policy, enabling admitted students to consider Notre Dame alongside other colleges they have been accepted to. Of the 3,577 admits, 1,400 (39.1%) were through this early action plan. These students came from 1,311 high schools, with an average travel distance of over 750 miles to attend Notre Dame, positioning it as one of the most representative universities in the U.S. While all new students start at the College of the First Year of Studies, their intended fields of study are diverse: 25% plan to focus on liberal arts or social sciences, while 24% each aim for engineering, business, and science, with 3% pursuing architecture.

data.text: Between 2015-2016, U.S. News & World Report's Best Colleges 2016 placed Notre Dame 18th overall among national universities in the U.S. In 2014, USA Today positioned Notre Dame 10th overall for American universities using data from College Factual. Forbes.com ranked Notre Dame 13th nationally in America's Best Colleges 2015, 8th among Research Universities, and first in the Midwest. Additionally, U.S. News & World Report listed Notre Dame Law School as 22nd overall. BusinessWeek rated Mendoza College of Business undergraduate program first overall and its MBA program 20th. The Philosophical Gourmet Report ranked Notre Dame's graduate philosophy program 15th nationally, while ARCHITECT Magazine placed the undergraduate architecture program 12th. Notably, Notre Dame's study abroad program had sixth-highest participation at 57.6% of students studying in 17 countries. According to payscale.com, University of Notre Dame alumni have a mid-career median salary of $110,000, ranking it 24th among U.S. colleges and universities, with a starting salary median of $55,300 ranked 58th within the same group.

data.text: Father Joseph Carrier, C.S.C., served as Director of the Science Museum and Library, as well as Professor of Chemistry and Physics until 1874. He advocated that scientific research and its potential for progress were compatible with the Church's intellectual and moral ideals. Among his students was Father John Augustine Zahm (1851–1921), who became a Professor and Co-Director of the Science Department at age 23, gaining national prominence as a scientist and naturalist by 1900. Zahm played a significant role in the Catholic Summer School movement, which engaged Catholic laypeople with contemporary intellectual matters. In his book "Evolution and Dogma" (1896), he argued for the validity of certain aspects of evolutionary theory and suggested that Church luminaries like Thomas Aquinas and Augustine had similar ideas. His potential censure by the Vatican was averted due to the intervention of Irish American Catholics in Rome. In 1913, Zahm joined former President Theodore Roosevelt on an extensive expedition through the Amazon.

data.text: In 1882, Albert Zahm, John Zahm's brother, constructed one of the earliest wind tunnels to evaluate the lift-to-drag ratios of aeronautical models. Circa 1899, Professor Jerome Green achieved the milestone of being the first American to transmit a wireless message. In 1931, Father Julius Nieuwland conducted foundational research on chemical reactions that later facilitated the development of neoprene. The study of nuclear physics at the university commenced with the construction of a nuclear accelerator in 1936 and persists today, partly through collaboration with the Joint Institute for Nuclear Astrophysics.

data.text: The Lobund Institute originated from groundbreaking research on germ-free life initiated in 1928. This field emerged from a question posed by Pasteur regarding the viability of animal life without bacteria. Although others explored this concept, their efforts were brief and inconclusive. The Lobund Institute was the first to definitively demonstrate that such life is feasible across generations. However, its goal extended beyond answering Pasteur's inquiry; it aimed to create germ-free animals as innovative tools for biological and medical research. This objective was successfully achieved, establishing Lobund as a unique hub for the study and production of germ-free animals used in various scientific investigations. The work has since expanded to other universities. Initially, it operated under the Department of Biology with a master's degree program complementing its research efforts. In the 1940s, Lobund attained independent status as a purely research-focused organization, achieving institute status by 1950. In 1958, it was reintegrated into the Department of Biology but maintained its own PhD program in Gnotobiotics.

data.text: Established in 1939 by Gurian, The Review of Politics was inspired by German Catholic publications and quickly gained prominence as part of an international Catholic intellectual resurgence. This journal provided an alternative to positivist philosophy. Over the course of 44 years, it was edited by Gurian, along with Matthew Fitzsimons, Frederick Crosson, and Thomas Stritch. Notable intellectual figures associated with it included Gurian, Jacques Maritain, Frank O'Malley, Leo Richard Ward, F. A. Hermens, and John U. Nef. It became a significant platform for political discourse and contemporary political issues, particularly those rooted in Catholic and scholastic traditions.

data.text:
As of 2014, Notre Dame had a student body of 12,179, including 8,448 undergraduates, 2,138 graduate and professional students, and 1,593 professional students specializing in Law, M.Div., Business, or M.Ed. Approximately 21–24% of the students are alumni's children. While 37% hail from the Midwestern United States, the student population represents all 50 states and over 100 countries.

In March 2007, The Princeton Review ranked Notre Dame as the fifth most desired school for parents to send their children. By March 2015, this ranking had shifted to ninth place. Historically, the university faced criticism for its lack of diversity; however, it was also rated highly by The Princeton Review as a school where "Alternative Lifestyles [are] Not an Alternative." Some publications have praised Notre Dame's diversity efforts: Hispanic Magazine ranked it ninth among top colleges for Latinos in 2004, and The Journal of Blacks in Higher Education noted its increase in African-American student enrollment in 2006.

The university boasts the largest intramural sports program, with 6,000 participants. In 2004, Sports Illustrated named it the best in the country, while The Princeton Review identified it as the leading school for "Everyone Plays Intramural Sports" in 2007. Notre Dame hosts the annual Bookstore Basketball tournament, recognized as the world's largest outdoor five-on-five basketball event with over 700 teams participating yearly. Additionally, the Notre Dame Men’s Boxing Club organizes the Bengal Bouts tournament to support Holy Cross Missions in Bangladesh.

data.text: Approximately 80% of undergraduate students and 20% of graduate students reside on campus. Most graduate students who live on campus are housed in one of four dedicated graduate housing complexes, while all on-campus undergraduates occupy one of the 29 residence halls. Due to the university's religious affiliation, all residence halls are single-sex: there are 15 male dormitories and 14 female ones. The university enforces a visiting policy (referred to as parietal hours) for students in dormitories, designating times when members of the opposite sex can visit other students' rooms; however, every residence hall provides 24-hour social spaces accessible to all genders. Many residence halls include at least one nun or priest among their residents. Although traditional fraternities and sororities are absent on campus, most students choose to reside in the same dorm for all four years. Certain intramural sports revolve around teams from different residence halls, with the university offering a unique full-contact American football program within its non-military academy intramurals. The season concludes with the championship game held at Notre Dame Stadium.

data.text: The university is associated with the Congregation of Holy Cross (Latin: Congregatio a Sancta Cruce, abbreviated postnominals: "CSC"). Although religious affiliation does not affect admissions, over 93% of students identify as Christian, and more than 80% are Catholic. Campus-wide, Catholic Masses occur more than 100 times per week, supported by an extensive campus ministry program that caters to the spiritual needs of the community. Numerous religious statues and artworks embellish the campus, notably including the statue of Mary on the Main Building, the Notre Dame Grotto, and the Word of Life mural at Hesburgh Library, which portrays Christ as a teacher. Every classroom features a crucifix. A variety of religious clubs (both Catholic and non-Catholic) are available, such as Council #1477 of the Knights of Columbus (KOC), Baptist Collegiate Ministry (BCM), Jewish Club, Muslim Student Association, Orthodox Christian Fellowship, The Mormon Club, among others. Notably, the Notre Dame KofC is recognized as the first collegiate council of KofC and runs a charitable concession stand during each home football game while owning a campus building that serves as a cigar lounge. There are fifty-seven chapels distributed throughout the campus.

data.text: In April 1879, a fire completely destroyed the Main Building and its library collection, prompting an immediate closure of the school and the dismissal of students. University founder Fr. Sorin and then-president Rev. William Corby promptly initiated plans to rebuild the structure that had accommodated nearly all university operations. Construction commenced on May 17th, and due to the dedicated efforts of administrators and workers, the building was finished before the fall semester began later that year. The library collection was also restored and remained in the new Main Building for many years. Around this period, a music hall was opened, which eventually became known as Washington Hall and served as a venue for school plays and musical performances. By 1880, a science program had been established at the university, leading to the construction of Science Hall (now LaFortune Student Center) in 1883. This building provided classrooms and laboratories essential for early research activities.

data.text: In 1919, Father James Burns assumed the presidency of Notre Dame and, within three years, initiated an academic transformation that elevated the institution to national standards by implementing an elective system and shifting away from its traditional focus on scholastic and classical studies. Meanwhile, Jesuit colleges, known for their academic conservatism, hesitated to adopt electives, resulting in their graduates being excluded from Harvard Law School. Over time, Notre Dame expanded, incorporating additional colleges, programs, and sports teams. By 1921, with the establishment of the College of Commerce, Notre Dame evolved from a modest college into a university comprising five colleges and a professional law school. The institution continued to grow under each new president, adding more residence halls and buildings.

data.text: A significant catalyst for the University's expansion was its football team, the Notre Dame Fighting Irish. Knute Rockne assumed the role of head coach in 1918 and achieved an impressive record with 105 victories, 12 defeats, and five draws. Over his 13-year tenure, the team secured three national championships, experienced five undefeated seasons, triumphed at the Rose Bowl in 1925, and produced notable players like George Gipp and the "Four Horsemen." Rockne holds the highest winning percentage (.881) in NCAA Division I/FBS football history. His offenses were characterized by the Notre Dame Box, while his defenses implemented a 7–2–2 scheme. The final game he coached took place on December 14, 1930, when he led a group of Notre Dame all-stars against the New York Giants in New York City.

data.text:
Notre Dame's football team gained widespread recognition, reflecting the elevated status of Irish Americans and Catholics during the 1920s. Catholic communities enthusiastically supported the team, particularly when they defeated institutions representing America's Protestant establishment, such as Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. However, Notre Dame's prominence as a leading Catholic institution made it susceptible to anti-Catholic sentiments.

A significant incident occurred in 1924 with violent confrontations between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan. Nativism and anti-Catholicism were central to the KKK’s rhetoric, particularly against immigrants, casting Notre Dame as a symbol of perceived threats posed by the Catholic Church. The Klan organized a week-long gathering in South Bend.

Tensions escalated on March 17 when informed students intercepted Klansmen at the South Bend train station, stripping them of their attire and symbols. On May 19, thousands of students gathered downtown to protest, with College President Fr. Matthew Walsh's intervention preventing further clashes. The following day, football coach Knute Rockne urged student compliance with the president’s guidance at a campus rally.

The Klavern disbanded shortly afterward, but the students' hostility foreshadowed and contributed to the KKK's decline in Indiana.

data.text: In 1933, Holy Cross Father John Francis O'Hara was appointed vice-president, followed by his election as president of Notre Dame in 1934. Throughout his presidency, he welcomed numerous refugee intellectuals to the campus and honored Frank H. Spearman, Jeremiah D. M. Ford, Irvin Abell, and Josephine Brownson with the Laetare Medal, established in 1883. O'Hara was a firm believer that the Fighting Irish football team could effectively promote Notre Dame's ideals to the public. He articulated this belief by stating, "Notre Dame football is a spiritual service because it is played for the honor and glory of God and His Blessed Mother. data.text:
Rev. John J. Cavanaugh, C.S.C., served as president from 1946 to 1952. During this post-war period, he focused on elevating academic standards and restructuring the university administration to align with its broadened educational goals and growing student body. He emphasized advanced studies and research at a time when Notre Dame's student population quadrupled, undergraduate enrollment increased by over half, and graduate student numbers grew fivefold.

Under his leadership, Cavanaugh founded the Lobund Institute for Animal Studies and the Medieval Institute at Notre Dame. He also oversaw the construction of Nieuwland Science Hall, Fisher Hall, Morris Inn, and O'Shaughnessy Hall (formerly the Hall of Liberal Arts), made possible by a record-breaking donation from I.A. O'Shaughnessy to an American Catholic university.

Additionally, Cavanaugh established advisory councils at the university that continue to play a crucial role in its governance and development today.

data.text: Rev. Theodore Hesburgh, C.S.C. (1917–2015), served as president for 35 years (1952–1987) during a period of significant transformation. During his tenure, the annual operating budget increased by a factor of 18 from $9.7 million to $176.6 million, and the endowment grew by a factor of 40 from $9 million to $350 million. Research funding expanded by a factor of 20 from $735,000 to $15 million. Enrollment nearly doubled from 4,979 to 9,600, faculty numbers more than doubled from 389 to 950, and the number of degrees awarded annually also doubled from 1,212 to 2,500.

data.text:
Hesburgh is recognized for transforming Notre Dame into a coeducational institution. In the mid-1960s, Notre Dame and Saint Mary’s College initiated a cooperative exchange program that allowed several hundred students to attend classes not available at their home institutions. This led to undergraduate women joining a campus already hosting some female graduate students. Despite considerable discussion, merging with St. Mary's was ultimately dismissed due to differences in faculty qualifications and salary scales.

The Rev. Charles E. Sheedy, C.S.C., Notre Dame’s Dean of Arts and Letters, noted that certain previously valued features in American college education are now perceived as outdated. He emphasized that in the current diverse environment, integrating sexes has become a standard expectation rather than maintaining separation. Thomas Blantz, C.S.C., Vice President of Student Affairs at Notre Dame, remarked that coeducation introduced access to another group of exceptionally talented students.

During the first year, two male residence halls were repurposed for newly admitted female students, with an additional two converted for the following academic year. In 1971, Mary Ann Proctor became the inaugural female undergraduate after transferring from St. Mary’s College. The subsequent year marked the graduation of Angela Sienko as the first woman to earn a bachelor's degree in marketing from Notre Dame.

Thomas Blantz, C.S.C., Vice President of Student Affairs at Notre Dame, mentioned that coeducation expanded access to another group of exceptionally talented students.

In its first year, two male residence halls were adapted for newly admitted female students, with an additional two converted in the subsequent academic year. In 1971, Mary Ann Proctor became the first female undergraduate after transferring from St. Mary’s College. The following year, Angela Sienko graduated as the first woman to earn a bachelor's degree in marketing from Notre Dame.

data.text: The University of Notre Dame has integrated sustainability leadership into its core mission by establishing the Office of Sustainability in 2008. This office focuses on several objectives across power generation, design and construction, waste reduction, procurement, food services, transportation, and water management. By 2012, four building projects were pursuing LEED-Certified status while three aimed for LEED Silver. Notre Dame's dining services procure 40% of its food from local sources and offer sustainably caught seafood along with numerous organic, fair-trade, and vegan options. On the Sustainable Endowments Institute's College Sustainability Report Card in 2010, the university received a "B" grade. Additionally, it hosts the Kroc Institute for International Peace Studies and includes Father Gustavo Gutierrez, founder of Liberation Theology, as a faculty member.

data.text: The ascension of Hitler and other authoritarian leaders during the 1930s compelled many Catholic intellectuals to escape Europe, with President John O'Hara facilitating their relocation to Notre Dame. Among them were Anton-Hermann Chroust (1907–1982), specializing in classics and law from Germany, and Waldemar Gurian, a German Catholic intellectual of Jewish heritage. While American intellectual life was heavily influenced by positivism starting in the 1920s, Gurian had been educated within the German Catholic tradition and completed his doctoral dissertation under Max Scheler. Renowned sculptor Ivan Meštrović (1883–1962) introduced Croatian culture to campus between 1955 and 1962. In the 1940s, Yves Simon (1903–61) brought insights from French studies in the Aristotelian-Thomistic philosophical tradition to Notre Dame; his mentor Jacques Maritain (1882–1973) frequently visited the campus as well.

In addition to its notable presence in athletics, Notre Dame is a substantial four-year residential research institution consistently ranked within the top twenty universities in the United States and recognized as a leading global university. The undergraduate program is structured into four colleges—Arts and Letters, Science, Engineering, Business—and the Architecture School, which is acclaimed for its New Classical Architecture teachings and the prestigious annual Driehaus Architecture Prize.

The graduate offerings include over 50 master's, doctoral, and professional programs across five schools, supplemented by Notre Dame Law School and an MD-PhD program in collaboration with IU Medical School. The university boasts a robust network of libraries, cultural centers, artistic and scientific museums, including the Hesburgh Library and Snite Museum of Art.

Approximately 80% of its 8,000 undergraduates reside on campus across 29 single-sex residence halls, each featuring unique traditions, legacies, events, and intramural sports teams. He initiated the school using an existing log chapel formerly occupied by Father Stephen Badin. data.text: The Fighting Irish is the nickname for Notre Dame's sports teams. As a member of NCAA Division I, they primarily participate in the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) for all sports since the 2013-14 school year. Previously, they competed in the Horizon League from 1982-83 to 1985-86 and again from 1987-88 to 1994-95, followed by participation in the Big East Conference through 2012-13. Men's sports encompass baseball, basketball, crew, cross country, fencing, football, golf, ice hockey, lacrosse, soccer, swimming & diving, tennis, and track & field; women's sports include basketball, cross country, fencing, golf, lacrosse, rowing, soccer, softball, swimming & diving, tennis, track & field, and volleyball. data.text:
In July 2013, Notre Dame altered its conference affiliations for most sports—excluding football and fencing—due to significant realignment activities. Its affiliation in fencing will adjust in July 2014. During a time of instability within the Big East, the Irish transitioned to the ACC, while maintaining independence in football but agreeing to play five games annually against ACC opponents. Following the Big Ten Conference's decision to incorporate ice hockey in the 2013–14 season, leading to several conference relocations and ultimately dissolving the Central Collegiate Hockey Association after the 2012–13 season, Notre Dame placed its hockey team within Hockey East.

Upon joining the ACC, the organization announced that fencing would be added as a sponsored sport from the 2014–15 academic year. The origins of the "Fighting Irish" moniker trace back to the early 1920s football team and were popularized by alumnus Francis Wallace through his columns in the New York Daily News. Notre Dame's official colors are Navy Blue and Gold Rush, which its teams wear during competitions. Additionally, green is frequently used due to the "Fighting Irish" nickname. The mascot for Notre Dame's athletic teams is the Notre Dame Leprechaun, created by Theodore W.

data.text: On July 1, 2014, a ten-year agreement was signed between the University of Notre Dame and Under Armour, whereby Under Armour committed to supplying uniforms, apparel, equipment, and providing financial compensation to Notre Dame. Valued at nearly $100 million, this contract stands as the most lucrative in NCAA history. The university marching band performs at home games for the majority of sports events. Established in 1846, the band claims the title of the oldest continuously existing university band in the United States. It was recognized by the National Music Council as a "Landmark of American Music" during the U.S. Bicentennial. The band regularly plays Notre Dame's fight song, the "Notre Dame Victory March," which has been named both the most played and most famous fight song by Northern Illinois Professor William Studwell. According to *College Fight Songs: An Annotated Anthology* (1998), the "Notre Dame Victory March" is considered the greatest fight song of all time.

data.text: The Notre Dame football team boasts a storied history that began when the Michigan Wolverines introduced the game to Notre Dame in 1887, facing off against student players. Since then, 13 Fighting Irish teams have secured consensus national championships (though the university officially claims only 11), with an additional nine recognized by at least one source. The program also holds the record for the most College Football Hall of Fame members, shares the highest number of Heisman Trophies won with Ohio State University, and boasts the greatest winning percentage in NCAA history. Over time, Notre Dame has developed numerous rivals; its annual contest against USC for the Jeweled Shillelagh is frequently cited as one of college football's most significant games and is often regarded as the premier intersectional rivalry in the nation.

data.text: George Gipp was Notre Dame’s legendary football player from 1916 to 1920. Outside sports, he engaged in semiprofessional baseball and indulged in smoking, drinking, and gambling. Known for his humility, generosity toward those in need, and integrity, Gipp became a symbol of inspiration when Knute Rockne famously urged the Notre Dame team in 1928 to "win one for the Gipper," referencing their last conversation with the ailing player before he passed away. The story was dramatized in the 1940 film *Knute Rockne, All American*, starring Pat O’Brien and Ronald Reagan. Presently, the Notre Dame football team plays at the Notre Dame Stadium on campus, which has an 80,795-seat capacity. Brian Kelly, hired from the University of Cincinnati on December 11, 2009, is the current head coach. Midway through his sixth season, Kelly's record stood at 52–21. In 2012, under his leadership, the Fighting Irish went undefeated and competed in the BCS National Championship Game. He succeeded Charlie Weis, who was dismissed in November 2009 after five seasons. Despite leading to two Bowl Championship Series games, Weis’s overall 35–27 record fell short of Notre Dame's standards, including a historically poor performance by the 2007 team. The football program operates independently with enough revenue and retains $22.1 million from its profits for academic purposes. Forbes valued the team at $101 million in 2007, making it the most valuable in college football.

data.text:
Football Gameday Traditions

Throughout home games, numerous activities take place on campus, with various dormitories adorning their halls with traditional items, such as Zahm House's two-story banner. The traditions commence at midnight with the Drummers' Circle, featuring the Band of the Fighting Irish drum line and setting the stage for gameday festivities that continue into Saturday. Later, the trumpet section performs the Notre Dame Victory March and the Alma Mater under the dome. Subsequently, the entire band presents a concert on Bond Hall's steps before leading fans and students across campus to the stadium.

data.text: The men’s basketball team boasts over 1,600 victories, placing it among just twelve schools to achieve this milestone. They have participated in 28 NCAA tournaments, with former player Austin Carr holding the record for most points in a single tournament game at 61. Despite never securing an NCAA Tournament win, they were twice declared national champions by the Helms Athletic Foundation. The team has notably disrupted multiple number-one ranked teams, including ending UCLA's 88-game winning streak in 1974. With nine victories over top-ranked teams, they hold the second-highest total after UCLA's ten. They compete at the renovated Purcell Pavilion within the Edmund P. Joyce Center, which reopened for the 2009–2010 season. Coach Mike Brey led the team to a 332-165 record by the 2014–15 season, his fifteenth year at Notre Dame. In 2009, they reached the NIT semifinals but lost to Penn State, who later defeated Baylor in the championship. The 2010–11 squad finished their regular season ranked seventh nationally with a 25–5 record, marking Brey's fifth consecutive 20-win season and a second-place finish in the Big East.

data.text: The "Notre Dame Victory March" serves as the fight song for the University of Notre Dame and was penned by two alumni brothers. Rev. Michael J. Shea, class of 1904, composed the music, while his brother John F. Shea, who graduated in 1906 and 1908, crafted the original lyrics. These lyrics underwent revisions in the 1920s before being first published under the University's copyright in 1928. The chorus proclaims: "Cheer cheer for old Notre Dame, wake up the echoes cheering her name. Send a volley cheer on high, shake down the thunder from the sky! What though the odds be great or small, old Notre Dame will win over all. While her loyal sons are marching, onward to victory!"

data.text: After Destiny's Child disbanded in June 2005, she launched her second solo album, B'Day (2006), featuring hits like "Déjà Vu," "Irreplaceable," and "Beautiful Liar." Beyoncé expanded into acting with a Golden Globe-nominated role in Dreamgirls (2006) and leading roles in The Pink Panther (2006) and Obsessed (2009). Her marriage to rapper Jay Z and her portrayal of Etta James in Cadillac Records (2008) inspired her third album, I Am... Sasha Fierce (2008), which introduced the alter-ego Sasha Fierce. This album won a record-breaking six Grammy Awards in 2010, including Song of the Year for "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)." Beyoncé took a break from music in 2010 to manage her career independently; her fourth album, 4 (2011), adopted a mellower tone, drawing influences from 1970s funk, 1980s pop, and 1990s soul. Her fifth studio album, Beyoncé (2013), was noted for its experimental production and exploration of darker themes, distinguishing it from previous releases.

data.text: Beyoncé, a self-proclaimed "modern-day feminist," crafts songs frequently revolving around themes such as love, relationships, monogamy, female sexuality, and empowerment. Her dynamic, meticulously choreographed stage performances have earned her acclaim from critics as one of the leading entertainers in contemporary popular music. Over a career spanning 19 years, she has sold more than 118 million records as a solo artist and an additional 60 million with Destiny's Child, positioning her among the top-selling musicians globally. With 20 Grammy Awards to her name, Beyoncé holds the record for most nominations by any female in its history. The Recording Industry Association of America acknowledged her as the Top Certified Artist in America during the 2000s. Billboard recognized her as the Top Radio Songs Artist of the Decade and Top Female Artist of the 2000s in 2009, later naming her their Artist of the Millennium in 2011. data.text: Beyoncé Giselle Knowles was born in Houston, Texas to Celestine Ann "Tina" Knowles (née Beyincé), a hairdresser and salon proprietor, and Mathew Knowles, who managed Xerox sales. Her name honors her mother's maiden name. Solange, Beyoncé's younger sister, is also a singer and was formerly part of Destiny's Child. While Mathew is African-American, Tina has Louisiana Creole roots, encompassing African, Native American, French, Cajun, and distant Irish and Spanish ancestry. Through her maternal lineage, Beyoncé descends from the Acadian leader Joseph Broussard and was brought up in a Methodist family.

data.text: Beyoncé began her education at St. Mary's Elementary School in Fredericksburg, Texas, where she took dance classes. Her singing talent emerged when Darlette Johnson, a dance instructor, started humming a tune, and Beyoncé completed it with ease, hitting the high notes effortlessly. After winning a school talent show at age seven by performing John Lennon's "Imagine" against older competitors aged 15/16, her passion for music and performance grew. In fall of 1990, she enrolled in Parker Elementary School, a specialized music magnet institution in Houston, participating with the choir there. Additionally, Beyoncé attended the High School for the Performing and Visual Arts, followed by Alief Elsik High School. She also served as a soloist in the choir at St. John's United Methodist Church for two years.

data.text:
At age eight, Beyoncé met childhood friend Kelly Rowland and LaTavia Roberson during an audition for an all-girl entertainment group. Together with three other girls, they formed Girl's Tyme, performing rap and dance routines on Houston's talent show circuit. R&B producer Arne Frager discovered them and brought them to his studio in Northern California for a spot on Star Search, the most prominent national TV talent show at that time. Despite their efforts, Girl's Tyme did not win; Beyoncé later commented that their performance song was subpar.

In 1995, Beyoncé’s father resigned from his job to manage the group, leading to a reduction in family income by half and necessitating her parents to live separately. Matthew restructured the lineup to four members, and they continued as an opening act for established R&B girl groups. After auditions with various record labels, they were signed to Elektra Records but moved briefly to Atlanta Records before being released from their contract. This decision strained family finances further, resulting in Beyoncé's parents' separation.

On October 5, 1995, Grass Roots Entertainment, led by Dwayne Wiggins, signed the group. By 1996, they began recording their debut album under a Sony Music agreement, prompting the Knowles family to reunite and subsequently secure a contract with Columbia Records.
data.label: gpt4

data.text:
In 1996, the group rebranded as Destiny's Child, inspired by a passage in the Book of Isaiah. They debuted their first major label single, "Killing Time," on the soundtrack for the 1997 movie *Men in Black*. In 1998, they released their self-titled debut album, which included the hit "No, No, No." The album established them as a significant presence in the music industry, with moderate sales and earning three Soul Train Lady of Soul Awards: Best R&B/Soul Album of the Year, Best New Artist (R&B/Soul or Rap), and Best R&B/Soul Single for "No, No, No."

In 1999, they launched their multi-platinum second album, *The Writing's on the Wall*, featuring hits like "Bills, Bills, Bills," their first number-one single, "Jumpin' Jumpin'," and "Say My Name," which became one of their most successful tracks at the time. The latter won Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals and Best R&B Song at the 43rd Annual Grammy Awards. The album sold over eight million copies globally. During this period, Beyoncé collaborated with Marc Nelson, an original member of Boyz II Men, on the track "After All Is Said and Done" for the *The Best Man* soundtrack in 1999.

data.text: LeToya Luckett and Roberson grew dissatisfied with Mathew's management of the group, leading to their replacement by Farrah Franklin and Michelle Williams. Following their departure, Beyoncé faced depression after being publicly blamed by the media, critics, and blogs for the split, compounded when her long-term boyfriend ended the relationship at that time. Her depression persisted for several years, during which she occasionally isolated herself in her bedroom for days and refused food. Beyoncé found it challenging to discuss her mental health struggles due to Destiny's Child having just won their first Grammy Award; she feared her concerns would not be taken seriously. She later credited her mother with helping her overcome this difficult period. Subsequently, Farrah Franklin was dismissed, leaving only Beyoncé, Rowland, and Williams in the group.

data.text: The remaining members recorded "Independent Women Part I," featured on the soundtrack for the 2000 movie *Charlie's Angels*. This track became their highest-charting single, leading the U.S. Billboard Hot 100 chart for eleven consecutive weeks. In early 2001, while Destiny's Child worked on their third album, Beyoncé secured a prominent role in the MTV television film *Carmen: A Hip Hopera*, starring alongside American actor Mekhi Phifer. The film, set in Philadelphia, offers a contemporary take on Georges Bizet's 19th-century opera *Carmen*. Upon releasing *Survivor* in May 2001, Luckett and Roberson sued, claiming the songs targeted them. The album debuted at number one on the U.S. Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 663,000 copies. It produced additional hits like "Bootylicious" and the title track "Survivor," which won a Grammy Award for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals. Following their holiday album *8 Days of Christmas* in October 2001, the group announced a hiatus to focus on solo endeavors.

In July 2002, Beyoncé advanced her acting career by portraying Foxxy Cleopatra alongside Mike Myers in the comedy film *Austin Powers in Goldmember*. The movie topped the U.S. box office during its opening weekend and earned $73 million. Beyoncé released "Work It Out" as the lead single from the soundtrack album, which charted in the top ten in the UK, Norway, and Belgium.

In 2003, she starred opposite Cuba Gooding, Jr., in the musical comedy *The Fighting Temptations*, playing Lilly, a single mother who becomes romantically involved with Gooding's character. Despite receiving mixed reviews from critics, the film grossed $30 million in the U.S. Beyoncé released "Fighting Temptation" as the lead single from the film’s soundtrack album, featuring Missy Elliott, MC Lyte, and Free, also used for promotional purposes. Her other contribution to the soundtrack, "Summertime," performed better on the US charts.

data.text: Beyoncé's debut solo appearance was on Jay Z’s track "'03 Bonnie & Clyde," released in October 2002, reaching number four on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100 chart. Her inaugural solo album, *Dangerously in Love*, launched on June 24, 2003, following solo releases by Michelle Williams and Kelly Rowland. The album sold 317,000 copies during its opening week, debuted at number one on the Billboard 200, and has since achieved global sales of over 11 million copies. Its lead single, "Crazy in Love," featuring Jay Z, marked Beyoncé’s first solo chart-topping hit in the U.S. Additionally, "Baby Boy" secured a number-one spot, while both "Me, Myself and I" and "Naughty Girl" reached the top five. data.text: In November 2003, she initiated the Dangerously in Love Tour across Europe before joining Missy Elliott and Alicia Keys for the Verizon Ladies First Tour in North America. On February 1, 2004, Beyoncé performed the American national anthem at Super Bowl XXXVIII, held at Reliant Stadium in Houston, Texas. Following the release of "Dangerously in Love," Beyoncé intended to create a follow-up album using leftover tracks but postponed this project to focus on recording "Destiny Fulfilled," Destiny's Child's final studio album. Released on November 15, 2004, in the U.S., and reaching number two on the Billboard 200, the album featured singles like "Lose My Breath" and "Soldier," which both made it into the top five of the Billboard Hot 100 chart. The group embarked on a global concert tour, Destiny Fulfilled... and Lovin' It. During their European leg's final stop in Barcelona on June 11, 2005, Rowland announced that Destiny's Child would disband after completing their North American tour. They released their first compilation album "Number 1's" on October 25, 2005, in the U.S., and received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in March 2006.

data.text:
In 2006, she made her acting debut in the comedy film *The Pink Panther*, starring alongside Steve Martin, which earned $158.8 million globally at the box office. Her next project was *Dreamgirls*, a movie adaptation of the 1981 Broadway musical inspired by The Supremes, receiving critical acclaim and earning $154 million internationally. In this film, she co-starred with Jennifer Hudson, Jamie Foxx, and Eddie Murphy as a pop singer reminiscent of Diana Ross. To promote *Dreamgirls*, Beyoncé released "Listen" as the lead single from its soundtrack album.

In April 2007, Beyoncé launched The Beyoncé Experience, her first global concert tour, which included performances at 97 venues and generated over $24 million. During six major stops on this tour, she organized pre-concert food drives in partnership with her pastor at St. John's and America’s Second Harvest. Concurrently, the album *B'Day* was re-released featuring five additional tracks, including her duet with Shakira titled "Beautiful Liar."

data.text: On April 4, 2008, Beyoncé married Jay Z. She publicly announced their marriage during a video montage at the listening party for her third studio album, *I Am... Sasha Fierce*, held on October 22, 2008, at Manhattan's Sony Club. The album was released in the United States on November 18, 2008. It formally introduced Beyoncé’s alter ego, Sasha Fierce, a persona conceived during the creation of her 2003 single "Crazy in Love." In its debut week, *I Am... Sasha Fierce* sold 482,000 copies, topping the Billboard 200 and marking Beyoncé's third consecutive number-one album in the US. The album included the number-one hit "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)" and top-five hits "If I Were a Boy" and "Halo." The success of "Halo" as her longest-running Hot 100 single helped Beyoncé achieve more top-ten singles than any other woman in the 2000s. Additionally, it featured popular tracks like "Sweet Dreams," along with the singles "Diva," "Ego," "Broken-Hearted Girl," and "Video Phone." The music video for "Single Ladies" has been widely parodied and imitated globally, earning recognition as the "first major dance craze" of the Internet age according to the Toronto Star. It won several accolades, including Best Video at the 2009 MTV Europe Music Awards, the 2009 Scottish MOBO Awards, and the 2009 BET Awards. At the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards, the video received nine nominations, winning three awards, among them Video of the Year.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: In addition to expanding her acting career, Beyoncé starred as blues singer Etta James in the 2008 musical biopic "Cadillac Records." Her performance earned critical acclaim and led to multiple award nominations, including a Satellite Award nomination for Best Supporting Actress and a NAACP Image Award nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actress. She generously donated her entire salary from the film to Phoenix House, an organization dedicated to rehabilitating heroin addicts nationwide. On January 20, 2009, Beyoncé performed Etta James' "At Last" at the First Couple's inaugural ball. In the thriller "Obsessed," she appeared alongside Ali Larter and Idris Elba as Sharon Charles, a mother and wife who becomes aware of another woman's obsession with her husband. Despite receiving negative reviews from critics, the film was commercially successful in the U.S., grossing $68 million—$60 million more than "Cadillac Records"—on a budget of $20 million. The climactic fight scene between Sharon and Ali Larter's character won the 2010 MTV Movie Award for Best Fight.

According to Rolling Stone, the music industry encouraged them to return their earnings from these concerts. Later that year, she became the first solo female artist in over two decades to headline Glastonbury Festival's main Pyramid stage and was recognized as the highest-paid performer globally per minute.

data.text: Her fourth studio album, *4*, was released in the US on June 28, 2011. It sold 310,000 copies during its first week and debuted at number one on the Billboard 200 chart, marking Beyoncé's fourth consecutive top-selling album in the United States. The album featured two lead singles, "Run the World (Girls)" and "Best Thing I Never Had," both of which achieved moderate success. Its fourth single, "Love on Top," enjoyed significant commercial success in the US. Additionally, *4* included four other singles: "Party," "Countdown," "I Care," and "End of Time." Beyoncé also won a writing award from the New York Association of Black Journalists for her cover story, "Eat, Play, Love," published by Essence, which chronicled her 2010 career break. In late 2011, she performed at New York's Roseland Ballroom over four nights in a series known as the 4 Intimate Nights with Beyoncé concerts, where she played songs from her *4* album to an enthusiastic, sold-out crowd.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: In January 2013, Destiny's Child released "Love Songs," a compilation of romance-themed tracks from their earlier albums along with a new recording titled "Nuclear." Beyoncé performed the American national anthem at President Obama's second inauguration in Washington, D.C., using a pre-recorded track. The following month, she headlined the Super Bowl XLVII halftime show at the Mercedes-Benz Superdome in New Orleans, which became the second most-tweeted event in history with 268,000 tweets per minute. At the 55th Annual Grammy Awards, Beyoncé won Best Traditional R&B Performance for "Love on Top." Her documentary film, "Life Is But a Dream," premiered on HBO on February 16, 2013; directed and produced by herself, it included footage from her childhood, motherhood, business ventures, rehearsals, live performances, and her return to the spotlight post-Blue Ivy's birth. The DVD release in November 2013 featured additional content from the Revel Presents: Beyoncé Live concerts and a new song, "God Made You Beautiful." In February 2013, Beyoncé entered into a global publishing agreement with Warner/Chappell Music for her future songwriting and upcoming studio album.

In February, she headlined the Super Bowl XLVII halftime show at New Orleans' Mercedes-Benz Superdome, becoming the event with the second-highest tweet rate at 268,000 tweets per minute. At the 55th Annual Grammy Awards, Beyoncé won Best Traditional R&B Performance for "Love on Top." Her documentary film, "Life Is But a Dream," premiered on HBO on February 16, 2013; directed and produced by her, it featured footage of her childhood, motherhood, business ventures, rehearsals, live performances, and resurgence following the birth of Blue Ivy. The November 2013 DVD release included additional content from the Revel Presents: Beyoncé Live concerts and a new track titled "God Made You Beautiful." In February 2013, Beyoncé signed a global publishing agreement with Warner/Chappell Music for her future songwriting projects and next studio album.

data.text:
On December 13, 2013, Beyoncé released her self-titled fifth studio album on the iTunes Store unexpectedly, without any prior announcement or promotion. The album debuted at number one on the Billboard 200 chart, marking her fifth consecutive top-charting album in the US and making her the first woman to have her first five studio albums debut at that position. Critical acclaim and commercial success followed, with a million digital copies sold worldwide within six days; The New York Times highlighted the significance of its unconventional release strategy. As an electro-R&B album exploring darker themes such as bulimia, postnatal depression, and marriage and motherhood insecurities—topics not previously addressed in her work—the single "Drunk in Love" featuring Jay Z peaked at number two on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.

In April 2014, Beyoncé and Jay Z announced their On the Run Tour after weeks of speculation, marking their first co-headlining stadium tour. On August 24, 2014, she received the Video Vanguard Award at the MTV Video Music Awards and won three competitive awards: Best Video with a Social Message and Best Cinematography for "Pretty Hurts," along with best collaboration for "Drunk in Love." In November, Forbes reported that Beyoncé was the highest-earning woman in music for the second consecutive year, earning $115 million, more than double her earnings from 2013.

data.text:
At the 57th Annual Grammy Awards in February 2015, Beyoncé received six nominations and won three awards: Best R&B Performance and Best R&B Song for "Drunk in Love," along with Best Surround Sound Album for *Beyoncé*. Although nominated for Album of the Year, she lost to Beck, whose album *Morning Phase* won. In August 2015, Beyoncé was featured on the cover of Vogue's September issue, making her the first African-American artist and the third African-American woman overall to do so. She performed at the Made in America festival in early September and later headlined the Global Citizen Festival that month. Additionally, she made an uncredited appearance on Coldplay's "Hymn for the Weekend" from their seventh studio album *A Head Full of Dreams*, released in December 2015.

On January 7, 2016, Pepsi announced that Beyoncé would perform with Coldplay at Super Bowl 50 in February. This marked her fifth Super Bowl performance, including as the main headliner at the 47th Super Bowl halftime show in 2013.

data.text: On January 7, 2012, Beyoncé welcomed her daughter, Blue Ivy Carter, at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York, with heightened security measures. Two days later, Jay Z released "Glory," a song dedicated to their newborn, on his website Lifeandtimes.com. The track recounts the couple's challenges during pregnancy, including a miscarriage that Beyoncé experienced prior to conceiving Blue Ivy. At the end of "Glory," Blue Ivy's cries are featured, and she was officially credited as "B.I.C." Within two days of her birth, Blue Ivy became the youngest individual ever listed on a Billboard chart when "Glory" premiered on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart.

data.text: Beyoncé and her husband, Jay Z, are friends with President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama. She performed "America the Beautiful" at the 2009 presidential inauguration and sang "At Last" during the first inaugural dance at the Neighborhood Ball two days later. For Obama's 2012 re-election campaign, Beyoncé and Jay Z organized a fundraiser at his 40/40 Club in Manhattan, raising $4 million. Beyoncé posted images of her paper ballot on Tumblr to confirm she voted for the Democratic Party and encourage others to do so. She performed the American national anthem with a pre-recorded track at Obama's second inauguration. On March 26, 2013, Beyoncé publicly endorsed same-sex marriage following the Supreme Court debate over California's Proposition 8. In July 2013, she and Jay Z attended a rally in response to George Zimmerman’s acquittal for Trayvon Martin's shooting.

data.text: Since 2008, *Forbes* magazine has tracked Beyoncé's earnings, noting that she earned $80 million between June 2007 and June 2008 from music, tours, films, and her clothing line. This income placed her above Madonna and Celine Dion as the top-earning music personality at the time. In 2009, *Forbes* ranked her fourth on its Celebrity 100 list and ninth in the "Most Powerful Women in the World" list. The following year, she was eighth on the "Best-Paid Celebrities Under 30" list, having earned $35 million from her clothing line and endorsements. In 2012, she ranked 16th on the Celebrity 100 list, with earnings of $40 million for her album *4*, clothing line, and endorsements—12 places lower than three years prior. That same year, Beyoncé and Jay Z topped the "World's Highest-Paid Celebrity Couples" list by earning $78 million together. They had also been recognized in the previous year’s Guinness World Records as the "highest-earning power couple," having earned $122 million in 2009. From 2009 to 2011, Beyoncé averaged earnings of $70 million annually and made $40 million in 2012. In 2013, her endorsements for Pepsi and H&M elevated her and Jay Z to become the first billion-dollar music industry couple. That year, *Forbes* ranked her as the fourth most-powerful celebrity.

data.text: Beyoncé's vocal range covers four octaves. Jody Rosen emphasizes the distinctiveness of her tone and timbre, describing her voice as "one of the most compelling instruments in popular music." Another critic characterizes her as a "vocal acrobat," noting her ability to perform long, complex melismas and runs effortlessly while staying on key. Her vocal prowess establishes her as the focal point of Destiny's Child. The Daily Mail describes Beyoncé's voice as "versatile," adept at exploring power ballads, soul, rock belting, operatic flourishes, and hip hop. Jon Pareles from The New York Times remarks that her voice is "velvety yet tart, with an insistent flutter and reserves of soulful belting." Rosen points out that Beyoncé's rhythmic vocal style is heavily influenced by the hip hop era, though she also remains traditional in her use of balladry, gospel, and falsetto. Other critics acclaim her range and power; Chris Richards from The Washington Post notes she can "punctuate any beat with goose-bump-inducing whispers or full-throated diva-roars."
data.label: gpt4

data.text: In 2001, she became the first African-American woman and second female songwriter to receive the Pop Songwriter of the Year award at the American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers Pop Music Awards. That year, Beyoncé joined an elite group as only the third woman—after Carole King in 1971 and Mariah Carey in 1991—to have songwriting credits on three number-one hits: "Irreplaceable," "Grillz," and "Check on It." She shares a place with American songwriter Diane Warren for having nine songwriting credits on number-one singles. Notably, Diane Warren penned her 9/11-inspired song "I Was Here" for Beyoncé's album titled *4*. In May 2011, Billboard magazine recognized Beyoncé as the seventeenth leading Hot 100 Songwriter of all time, noting she co-wrote eight singles that reached number one on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. She was among just three women included on this list.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: Beyoncé cites Michael Jackson as a pivotal influence in her music career. At the age of five, she attended her first concert featuring Jackson, which helped her discover her calling. During a tribute presentation at the World Music Awards in 2006, Beyoncé stated, "If it weren't for Michael Jackson, I would never have performed." She regards Diana Ross as an exceptional entertainer and credits Whitney Houston with inspiring her to emulate her performances. Beyoncé acknowledges Mariah Carey's impact on her vocal technique, particularly through the song "Vision of Love," which encouraged her to practice vocal runs in childhood. Her other influences include Aaliyah, Prince, Lauryn Hill, Sade Adu, Donna Summer, Mary J. Blige, Janet Jackson, Anita Baker, and Rachelle Ferrell.

data.text: In The New Yorker, music critic Jody Rosen hailed Beyoncé as "the most important and compelling popular musician of the twenty-first century... the culmination, the natural conclusion, of over a century of pop." When The Guardian named her Artist of the Decade, Llewyn-Smith explained, "Why Beyoncé? [...] She produced not just one but two of the decade's greatest singles—'Crazy in Love' and 'Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)'—in addition to her hits with Destiny's Child. This was also the era when singles, especially R&B ones, reclaimed their status as pop's preferred format. [...] [She] rather than any aging rock star could arguably be considered the greatest live performer over the past decade." In 2013, Beyoncé appeared on the Time 100 list, with Baz Luhrmann noting, "No one possesses her voice, moves like she does, or captivates an audience as she does... Whenever Beyoncé releases an album, sings a song, or performs any act, it's considered an event and widely influential. Currently, she is seen as the heir-apparent diva of the USA—the reigning national voice." In 2014, Beyoncé featured again on the Time 100 list and graced the cover of that issue.

During this period, R&B singles reclaimed their status as pop's preferred format. [...] [She] could be seen as the most exceptional live performer of the past decade, surpassing any aging rock star." In 2013, Beyoncé was featured on Time magazine's 100 Most Influential People list, with Baz Luhrmann noting, "No one commands her voice, moves as she does, or captivates an audience like she does... Any album release, song, or performance by Beyoncé is considered a significant event and wields considerable influence. Currently, she stands as the presumptive leading diva of the USA—the nation's dominant voice." In 2014, Beyoncé was included on the Time 100 list once more and featured on its cover.

data.text:
Her debut single, "Crazy in Love," was hailed as VH1's "Greatest Song of the 2000s," NME's "Best Track of the 00s" and "Pop Song of the Century." Rolling Stone recognized it as one of the 500 greatest songs ever. It garnered two Grammy Awards and sold approximately eight million copies, making it one of the best-selling singles globally.

The music video for "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)" gained acclaim for its intricate choreography and use of jazz hands. The Toronto Star credited it with initiating "the first major dance craze of both the new millennium and the Internet," sparking numerous parodies and inspiring many amateur imitators on YouTube.

In 2013, Drake released "Girls Love Beyoncé," which included an interpolation from Destiny's Child's "Say My Name" and explored his relationships with women. In January 2012, Bryan Lessard, a research scientist, named Scaptia beyonceae, a horse fly species found in Northern Queensland, Australia, after Beyoncé because of its distinctive golden hairs on the abdomen.

In July 2014, an exhibit featuring Beyoncé was inaugurated at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's "Legends of Rock" section. Among the pieces displayed are her black leotard from the "Single Ladies" music video and her Super Bowl halftime show outfit.

data.text: Beyoncé has garnered numerous accolades throughout her career. As a solo artist, she has sold over 15 million albums in the US and more than 118 million records globally; this figure rises to an additional 60 million when including sales with Destiny's Child, establishing her as one of history's top-selling music artists. The Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) recognized Beyoncé as the leading certified artist of the 2000s, boasting a total of 64 certifications. Her tracks "Crazy in Love," "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)," "Halo," and "Irreplaceable" are among the highest-selling singles worldwide. In 2009, The Observer named her Artist of the Decade, while Billboard honored her as the Top Female Artist and Top Radio Songs Artist of that decade. By 2010, Billboard placed her at number 15 on their "Top 50 R&B/Hip-Hop Artists of the Past 25 Years" list. In 2012, VH1 ranked Beyoncé third among the "100 Greatest Women in Music." She holds the distinction of being the first female artist to receive the International Artist Award at the American Music Awards. Additionally, she has been awarded the Legend Award at the 2008 World Music Awards and the Billboard Millennium Award at the 2011 Billboard Music Awards.

data.text:
Beyoncé has earned 20 Grammy Awards as both a solo artist and member of Destiny's Child, ranking her second among female artists recognized by the Grammys, just behind Alison Krauss. She also holds the record for the most Grammy nominations received by a woman, with 52 in total. Her song "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)" took home the Song of the Year award in 2010, while "Say My Name" and "Crazy in Love" had earlier won Best R&B Song. Albums Dangerously in Love, B'Day, and I Am... Sasha Fierce each received accolades for Best Contemporary R&B Album.

In a single night during 2010, Beyoncé shattered the record by winning six Grammy Awards, surpassing the previous tie held by Alicia Keys, Norah Jones, Alison Krauss, and Amy Winehouse. This achievement was later matched by Adele in 2012. After her role in Dreamgirls, she received nominations for Best Original Song ("Listen") at the Golden Globe Awards and Outstanding Actress in a Motion Picture at the NAACP Image Awards. Additionally, Beyoncé won two awards at the 2006 Broadcast Film Critics Association Awards: Best Song for "Listen" and Best Original Soundtrack for Dreamgirls: Music from the Motion Picture.

data.text: Beyoncé has been collaborating with Pepsi since 2002; notably, she featured alongside Britney Spears, Pink, and Enrique Iglesias in a Gladiator-themed advertisement in 2004. In 2012, Beyoncé secured a $50 million endorsement contract with Pepsi. The Center for Science in the Public Interest (CSPINET) addressed her with an open letter, urging reconsideration of the deal due to health concerns associated with the product and suggesting that she donate the earnings to a medical organization. Despite this, NetBase reported in April 2013 that Beyoncé's campaign was the most discussed endorsement, receiving a 70 percent positive response from audiences regarding both the commercial and print advertisements.

In February 2011, she introduced her second perfume, Heat Rush. Her third scent, Pulse, was released in September 2011. data.text: On March 30, 2015, Beyoncé was revealed as a co-owner, alongside various other artists, in the music streaming service Tidal, which specializes in lossless audio and high-definition music videos. In early 2015, Jay Z acquired Aspiro, the parent company of Tidal. The ownership group includes Beyoncé, Jay-Z, and fifteen other artist stakeholders such as Kanye West, Rihanna, Madonna, Chris Martin, and Nicki Minaj, with most holding a 3% equity stake. This all-artist-owned service was established to meet the growing demand for streaming in the music industry and to compete with services like Spotify, which have faced criticism for their low royalty payouts. Jay-Z emphasized on Tidal's launch that the challenge lies in reestablishing respect for and recognition of the value of music.

The brand is managed under Beyond Productions, founded by Beyoncé and her mother, which handles licensing and brand management for House of Deréon and its junior line, Deréon. In April 2011, she partnered with First Lady Michelle Obama and the National Association of Broadcasters Education Foundation to promote their anti-child obesity campaign by remixing "Get Me Bodied." Following Osama bin Laden's death, Beyoncé released a rendition of Lee Greenwood’s “God Bless the USA” as a charity single to support the New York Police and Fire Widows' and Children's Benefit Fund.

data.text:
In December, Beyoncé collaborated with other celebrities to create a video campaign for "Demand A Plan," a bipartisan initiative led by 950 U.S. mayors aimed at urging federal government reconsideration of gun control laws following the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting. In 2012, Beyoncé served as an ambassador for World Humanitarian Day, contributing her song "I Was Here" and its music video, filmed at the UN, to the campaign.

In 2013, it was revealed that she would partner with Salma Hayek and Frida Giannini on a Gucci "Chime for Change" initiative focused on promoting female empowerment. The campaign aired on February 28 and featured her latest music. A London concert supporting this cause took place on June 1, featuring acts like Ellie Goulding, Florence and the Machine, and Rita Ora.

Ahead of the concert, Beyoncé appeared in a promotional video released on May 15, alongside Cameron Diaz, John Legend, and Kylie Minogue, sharing how their mothers inspired them. Other artists also highlighted personal inspirations from various women, encouraging viewers to submit photos of influential women; selected images were displayed at the concert. Regarding her mother Tina Knowles, Beyoncé remarked that her gift was "finding the best qualities in every human being."

Using the crowdfunding platform Catapult during the concert allowed attendees to support projects promoting education for women and girls.

data.text: Montana (pronounced /mɒnˈtænə/) is a state located in the Western United States. Its name originates from the Spanish word "montaña," meaning mountain. While it has several unofficial nicknames, such as "Big Sky Country" and "The Treasure State," its slogans include "Land of the Shining Mountains" and more recently "The Last Best Place." Montana ranks 4th in land area among the U.S. states but is 44th in population and 48th in population density. The state's western third features numerous mountain ranges, with smaller island ranges scattered throughout its territory. In total, 77 named ranges belong to the Rocky Mountains within Montana.

data.text:
Montana's schoolchildren were instrumental in selecting several state symbols. In a 1908 referendum, they overwhelmingly chose the ponderosa pine as the preferred state tree; however, it wasn't until 1949 that the legislature officially designated it. The Montana Federation of Garden Clubs, backed by the state forester, advocated for this formal recognition.

In 1930, schoolchildren selected the western meadowlark as the state bird through a vote, and the legislature confirmed their choice in 1931. In 1981, a children's vote sponsored by the secretary of state determined the grizzly bear to be the state animal, with a 2–1 margin over the elk after considering 74 nominations.

Additionally, Livingston students initiated a statewide petition drive and lobbied both the governor and legislature in 1985 to designate Maiasaura as the state fossil.

data.text:
Montana schoolchildren played an essential role in selecting several state symbols. In a 1908 referendum, they decisively chose the ponderosa pine as their preferred state tree; however, it wasn't until 1949 that this selection was officially acknowledged by the legislature. The formal designation came about through efforts from the Montana Federation of Garden Clubs and support from the state forester.

In 1930, schoolchildren voted for the western meadowlark to become the state bird, a decision ratified by the legislature in 1931. In 1981, under a vote organized by the secretary of state involving children, the grizzly bear was selected as the state animal by a margin of 2–1 over the elk from among 74 nominations.

Additionally, Livingston students spearheaded a statewide petition and lobbied both the governor and legislature in 1985 to designate Maiasaura as the state fossil.

data.text: The state song was composed 21 years after achieving statehood, during September 1910, when Joseph E. Howard's musical troupe visited Butte. At an after-show gathering, a former troupe member residing in Butte persuaded Howard to write a song about Montana with the assistance of Charles C. Cohan, the city editor for the Butte Miner newspaper. Together, they quickly devised a basic melody and lyrics within half an hour to entertain partygoers, refining it later that evening, with a final arrangement completed the next day. Upon their arrival in Helena, Howard's troupe performed 12 encores of the new song to an eager audience, prompting the governor to declare it the state song on the spot; however, formal legislative recognition was granted only in 1945. Montana is one of just three states with a "state ballad," "Montana Melody," selected by the legislature in 1983. Additionally, Montana holds the distinction of being the first state to adopt an official State Lullaby.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: Created 21 years after achieving statehood, the state song originated in September 1910 when Joseph E. Howard's musical troupe visited Butte. Following a performance, an ex-troupe member from Butte urged Howard to pen a song about Montana, with assistance from Charles C. Cohan, the city editor of the Butte Miner newspaper. Together, they rapidly produced a basic melody and lyrics in half an hour for their audience's enjoyment, refining it later that evening and finalizing it by the next day. Upon arriving in Helena, Howard’s troupe performed the new song 12 times at the request of an eager crowd, prompting the governor to immediately declare it the state song; though formal legislative recognition occurred in 1945. Additionally, Montana holds the unique distinction of being the first state to adopt an official State Lullaby.

data.text: The motto of Montana, Oro y Plata, which translates to "Gold and Silver," highlights the importance of mining and was first embraced in 1865 when Montana was a territory. During the initial session of the territorial legislature in 1864–65, a state seal featuring a miner's pick and shovel above the motto, encircled by mountains and the Great Falls of the Missouri River, was established. This design underwent minor changes after Montana achieved statehood and adopted it as its Great Seal, formalized by the legislature in 1893. In 1895, with backing from the Floral Emblem Association—a group formed following its adoption as a symbol by Montana's Women's Christian Temperance Union—the bitterroot was designated as the state flower. Throughout most of the 20th century, other symbols were selected, except for the state butterfly, the mourning cloak, which became official in 2001, and the state lullaby, "Montana Lullaby," adopted in 2007.

The territorial legislature's inaugural session in 1864–65 established a state seal that depicted a miner's pick and shovel above the motto, surrounded by mountains and the Great Falls of the Missouri River. After gaining statehood, minor alterations were made to this design, which was then formalized as Montana’s Great Seal by the legislature in 1893.

In 1895, with support from the Floral Emblem Association—established after its endorsement as a symbol by Montana's Women's Christian Temperance Union—the bitterroot flower was named the state flower. While most of the 20th century saw no additional symbols added, the mourning cloak butterfly gained official status in 2001, and "Montana Lullaby" became the state lullaby in 2007.

data.text:
The motto "Oro y Plata," meaning "Gold and Silver," highlights Montana's mining heritage and was first adopted as a territory in 1865. The territorial legislature established this during its initial session of 1864–65, creating a state seal featuring a miner’s pick and shovel above the motto, encircled by mountains and the Great Falls of the Missouri River. After achieving statehood, slight modifications to this design were made, and it was officially recognized as Montana's Great Seal by the legislature in 1893.

In 1895, following approval from the Floral Emblem Association—founded after its recommendation by Montana's Women's Christian Temperance Union—the bitterroot flower was designated as the state flower. The majority of the 20th century saw no further additions to state symbols; however, the mourning cloak butterfly was officially recognized in 2001, and "Montana Lullaby" became the state lullaby in 2007.
data.label: qwen_2

data.text: The state comprises five Micropolitan Statistical Areas centered on Bozeman, Butte, Helena, Kalispell, and Havre. These communities, with the exception of Havre, are informally referred to as the "big 7" Montana cities. They consistently rank as the seven largest communities in Montana, exhibiting a notable population gap compared to those ranked eighth or lower. According to the 2010 U.S. Census, Montana's seven most populous cities, listed by size, are Billings, Missoula, Great Falls, Bozeman, Butte, Helena, and Kalispell. Based on 2013 census data, these cities collectively account for 35 percent of Montana’s population, while the counties containing them hold 62 percent of the state's total population. The geographic center of Montana’s population is situated in sparsely populated Meagher County, specifically in White Sulphur Springs.

data.text: Montana is divided into 56 counties according to the United States Census Bureau, which identifies a total of 364 "places." This includes 129 incorporated places—comprising 52 cities, 75 towns, and two consolidated city-counties—and 235 census-designated places. Among these, Billings stands out as the sole city with a population exceeding 100,000, while Missoula and Great Falls each have populations over 50,000. These three communities serve as the focal points of Montana's three Metropolitan Statistical Areas.

data.text: The name "Montana" originates from the Spanish word "Montaña," meaning "mountain" or more broadly, "mountainous country." Early Spanish explorers referred to the entire mountainous region in the west as "Montaña del Norte." In a bill drafted by the United States House Committee on Territories—then led by Rep. James Ashley of Ohio—the name Montana was proposed for the territory that would later become Idaho Territory. Representatives Henry Wilson from Massachusetts and Benjamin F. Harding from Oregon successfully advocated changing this designation, arguing that Montana lacked significance. When Rep. Ashley introduced a bill in 1864 to establish a temporary government for a new territory carved out of Idaho, he again selected "Montana Territory." This choice faced opposition from Rep. Samuel Cox of Ohio, who argued that the name was inaccurate since most of the area wasn't mountainous and suggested using a Native American name instead of a Spanish one. While alternatives like "Shoshone" were proposed, it was ultimately decided that the Committee on Territories had the authority to choose any name, leading them to adopt Montana as the official designation.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: Montana covers an area of 147,040 square miles (380,800 km²), making it slightly larger than Japan. As the fourth-largest state in the U.S., following Alaska, Texas, and California, it is also the largest landlocked state and ranks as the 56th largest national subdivision globally. To its north, Montana shares a 545-mile (877 km) border with three Canadian provinces: British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan—uniquely bordered by these three. It is adjacent to North Dakota and South Dakota to the east, Wyoming to the south, and Idaho to the west and southwest.

data.text: The Continental Divide largely delineates Montana's topography by dividing it into distinct eastern and western regions. The majority of Montana’s over 100 named mountain ranges are located in the western half, which belongs to the Northern Rocky Mountains geologically and geographically. In the south-central region, the Absaroka and Beartooth ranges are technically part of the Central Rocky Mountains. A prominent feature in north-central Montana is the Rocky Mountain Front, while several isolated island ranges punctuate the prairie landscape typical of the central and eastern areas. Approximately 60 percent of the state consists of prairies within the northern Great Plains.
