data.text:
The deterioration of Chopin's relationship with Sand began in 1846 due to issues concerning her daughter Solange and Solange’s fiancé, the opportunistic young sculptor Auguste Clésinger. Chopin often sided with Solange during disputes with her mother and faced jealousy from Sand’s son Maurice. While he was completely indifferent to Sand's radical political activities, she looked down on his social circle. As Chopin's illness worsened, Sand transitioned from being a lover to acting as a caretaker, referring to him affectionately as her "third child." In correspondence with others, she expressed frustration by calling him a "child," a "little angel," a "sufferer," and a "beloved little corpse."

In 1847, Sand released the novel *Lucrezia Floriani*, featuring characters resembling herself and Chopin—a wealthy actress and an ailing prince—which were perceived as critical of Chopin. Given that he assisted her in correcting proofs for the book, it is likely he recognized these implications. That same year, Chopin did not visit Nohant, opting to discreetly conclude their decade-long relationship after a contentious exchange, which Sand described as marking "a strange conclusion to nine years of exclusive friendship." The pair never met again afterward.

data.text:
The deterioration in the relationship between Chopin and Sand commenced in 1846, largely due to conflicts involving Solange, Sand's daughter, and her fiancé, the ambitious sculptor Auguste Clésinger. Chopin often supported Solange during disagreements with her mother, which fueled jealousy from Sand’s son Maurice. Although indifferent to Sand's radical political pursuits, Chopin faced criticism for his social circle. As Chopin's health worsened, Sand transitioned from lover to caregiver, affectionately referring to him as her "third child." In correspondence, she occasionally expressed exasperation by calling him a "child," a "little angel," a "sufferer," and a "beloved little corpse."

In 1847, Sand released the novel *Lucrezia Floriani*, featuring characters that reflected both herself and Chopin—a wealthy actress and an ill prince—viewed as critical of Chopin. Given his assistance with proofreading, it is probable he understood these implications. That year, Chopin chose to avoid visiting Nohant, opting for a quiet end to their ten-year relationship following a heated argument, which Sand described as "a strange conclusion to nine years of exclusive friendship." They never saw each other again thereafter.
data.label: qwen_2

data.text: Chopin's compositional output gradually diminished over this period. In 1841, he composed a dozen works, but in 1842, only six were completed, followed by six shorter pieces in 1843. By 1844, he had written solely the Op. 58 sonata. The year 1845 saw the completion of three mazurkas (Op. 59). Although these compositions were more refined than many of his earlier works, Zamoyski suggests that "his ability to concentrate was waning and his inspiration faced both emotional and intellectual turmoil."

data.text: The life of Chopin and his relationship with George Sand have been depicted in various films. data.text: Chopin's compositions continue to enjoy widespread popularity, with frequent performances, recordings, and broadcasts globally. The International Chopin Piano Competition, established in 1927 and held every five years in Warsaw, is recognized as the oldest monographic music competition worldwide. According to the Fryderyk Chopin Institute of Poland, there are over eighty societies around the world dedicated to promoting the composer and his music. As of January 2014, nearly 1,500 performances of Chopin's works can be found on YouTube, according to the Institute's website.

data.text: In London, Chopin resided at Dover Street lodgings where Broadwood supplied him with a grand piano. During his inaugural performance on May 15th at Stafford House, attendees included Queen Victoria and Prince Albert. The musically skilled Prince moved near the keyboard to observe Chopin's technique closely. Broadwood also organized concerts for him, which were attended by figures such as Thackeray and singer Jenny Lind. Additionally, Chopin was in demand for piano lessons, charging a premium rate of one guinea (£1.05 today) per hour, and received 20 guineas for private recitals. At a concert on July 7th, he performed alongside Viardot, who sang his mazurkas set to Spanish texts.

data.text: In late summer, Jane Stirling extended an invitation for him to visit Scotland, where he resided at Calder House near Edinburgh and Johnstone Castle in Renfrewshire—both properties owned by her family members. She seemed intent on deepening their relationship beyond friendship, prompting him to clarify that such a development was not possible. During this period, he remarked to Grzymała about his Scottish acquaintances: "My Scottish ladies are kind, but such bores." In response to rumors regarding his personal life, he quipped: "I am closer to the grave than the nuptial bed." He performed at a public concert in Glasgow on September 27 and another in Edinburgh at the Hopetoun Rooms on Queen Street (now Erskine House) on October 4. While staying at 10 Warriston Crescent in Edinburgh with Polish physician Adam Łyszczyński, he drafted his last will and testament in late October 1848, humorously describing it to Grzymała as "a kind of disposition to be made of my stuff in the future, if I should drop dead somewhere."

data.text: In late November, Chopin made his way back to Paris. He spent the winter enduring persistent illness yet continued to offer occasional lessons and received visits from friends like Delacroix and Franchomme. At times, he performed or accompanied Delfina Potocka's singing for their gatherings. In the summer of 1849, his friends arranged for him an apartment in Chaillot, somewhat removed from the city center, funded secretly by an admirer, Princess Obreskoff. It was here that Jenny Lind visited him in June 1849.

data.text: As Chopin's health continued to decline, he wished for the presence of a family member. In June 1849, his sister Ludwika arrived in Paris with her husband and daughter. By September, thanks to a loan from Jane Stirling, he secured an apartment at Place Vendôme 12. After October 15th, when his health sharply worsened, only several close friends stayed by his side. Viardot cynically noted that "all the distinguished ladies of Paris felt it obligatory to faint in his room."

data.text: At his request, some friends provided music; notably, Potocka sang while Franchomme played the cello. Chopin insisted on having his body examined post-mortem due to fears of premature burial and desired that his heart be returned to Warsaw for interment at the Church of the Holy Cross. He also entrusted Alkan with completing his unfinished piano tuition method, Projet de méthode, upon his death. On the night of October 17, after midnight, the physician inquired if Chopin was in significant pain; he responded, "No longer." He passed away just minutes before two a.m. Present at his deathbed were his sister Ludwika, Princess Marcelina Czartoryska, Solange (Sand's daughter), and close friend Thomas Albrecht. Later that morning, Clésinger, Solange’s husband, created Chopin’s death mask and a cast of his left hand.

data.text: The precise nature of Chopin's illness and the cause of his demise remain subjects of debate. His death certificate cited tuberculosis, with his physician, Jean Cruveilhier, a prominent French expert on this disease, endorsing this diagnosis. Other potential causes have been proposed, such as cystic fibrosis, cirrhosis, and alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. Nevertheless, the identification of tuberculosis as the main cause has not been refuted. DNA testing that could potentially resolve these uncertainties was denied by the Polish government.

data.text: Mozart’s Requiem was performed at the funeral by soloists soprano Jeanne-Anais Castellan, mezzo-soprano Pauline Viardot, tenor Alexis Dupont, and bass Luigi Lablache. Led by Prince Adam Czartoryski, the funeral procession to Père Lachaise Cemetery included Chopin’s sister Ludwika. The pallbearers comprised Delacroix, Franchomme, and Camille Pleyel. data.text: Chopin received education steeped in the traditions of Beethoven, Haydn, Mozart, and Clementi; he utilized Clementi's piano method with his students. He was influenced by Hummel’s advancement of a virtuoso yet Mozartian piano technique. He acknowledged Bach and Mozart as pivotal composers in forming his musical perspective. Chopin's early compositions mirrored the "brilliant" keyboard pieces popular during his time, akin to those by Ignaz Moscheles and Friedrich Kalkbrenner, among others. In his initial works, influences from Polish folk music and Italian opera were subtler. Many aspects of his characteristic ornamentation style (such as fioriture) derived from singing techniques. His melodic lines increasingly reflected the modes and characteristics of his native country’s music, including drones.

data.text: Chopin elevated the nocturne, a new salon genre introduced by Irish composer John Field, to unprecedented levels of sophistication. He pioneered writing ballades and scherzi as standalone concert pieces. With his independent set of preludes (Op. 28, published in 1839), he effectively created a novel genre. Expanding on the poetic potential of the concert étude concept, which Liszt, Clementi, and Moscheles were developing since the 1820s and 1830s, Chopin introduced his two sets of studies (Op. 10, published in 1833; Op. 25, in 1837).

data.text: Chopin enhanced popular dance forms by expanding their melodic range and expressive depth. Although his mazurkas derived from the traditional Polish dance, they diverged by being composed for concert performances instead of social dances, establishing the mazurka's presence in European music culture. His published series of seven polonaises during his lifetime, complemented by nine additional pieces released posthumously and starting with Op. 26 (1836), established a new benchmark for this musical genre. Similarly, Chopin crafted his waltzes specifically for salon recitals rather than ballrooms, often featuring tempos faster than those typically used on the dance floor.

data.text: Some of Chopin's famous compositions are known by descriptive titles, like the Revolutionary Étude (Op. 10, No. 12) and the Minute Waltz (Op. 64, No. 1). Except for his Funeral March, Chopin did not assign specific names to his instrumental works beyond genre and number, allowing any extramusical interpretations to arise from listeners; these titles were later attributed by others. There is no evidence indicating that the Revolutionary Étude was composed with the failed Polish revolt against Russia in mind; it merely coincided with that period. The Funeral March, which serves as the third movement of his Sonata No. 2 (Op. 35), represents the only instance where he provided a title. This piece predates the rest of the sonata and is not associated with any particular event or death.

data.text: Chopin's final self-assigned opus number was 65, designated for the Cello Sonata in G minor. He made a deathbed request for all his unpublished manuscripts to be destroyed. However, following appeals from his mother and sisters, his musical executor, Julian Fontana, selected 23 unpublished piano works, organizing them into eight additional opus numbers (Opp. 66–73) published in 1855. In 1857, a collection of 17 Polish songs composed at different times in Chopin's life was released as Op. 74; the arrangement within this opus did not follow their chronological order of creation.

data.text: Chopin’s initial publishers were Maurice Schlesinger and Camille Pleyel. His compositions quickly became featured in renowned 19th-century piano collections. The first complete edition was released by Breitkopf & Härtel from 1878 to 1902. Both editions provide extensive explanations and analyses concerning editorial decisions and sources.

data.text: Improvisation plays a central role in Chopin's creative processes, though it does not equate to spontaneous meandering. Nicholas Temperley notes that "improvisation is crafted for an audience and begins with their expectations, including current musical form conventions." According to Temperley, the piano and orchestra works, including the two concertos, serve primarily as platforms for dazzling piano performances and are seen as "formally protracted and quite conservative." Following his early piano concertos from 1830, Chopin did not pursue large-scale multi-movement forms except in his late sonatas for piano and cello. Instead, he reached near-perfection with pieces characterized by simple overall structures but intricate internal frameworks. Rosen highlights that a key element of Chopin's uniqueness is his flexible manipulation of the four-bar phrase as a structural component.

data.text: Schumann referred to the preludes, many of which are notably concise and often focus on a single theme or motif, as "the beginnings of studies." Influenced by J.S. Bach's *The Well-Tempered Clavier*, Chopin crafted his preludes in a progression through the circle of fifths instead of following Bach's chromatic sequence, resulting in a distinct prelude for each major and minor key. Although it is unclear if these preludes were intended to be performed collectively, they might have served as introductory pieces to other compositions by Chopin or even works by different composers. As Kenneth Hamilton suggests, this practice was observed in Ferruccio Busoni's 1922 recording, where the Prelude Op. 28 No. 7 is succeeded by the Étude Op. 10 No. 5.

data.text: The two mature piano sonatas (No. 2, Op. 35, composed in 1839, and No. 3, Op. 58, composed in 1844) consist of four movements each. In Op. 35, Chopin successfully integrated various aspects of his virtuosic piano technique within a substantial musical framework, creating "a dialogue between the public flair of the brilliant style and the German sonata principle." The final movement, a concise (75-bar) perpetuum mobile where both hands play in continuous octave unison, was perceived as shocking and unmusical by contemporaries, including Schumann. The Op. 58 sonata aligns more closely with the German tradition, featuring numerous passages of intricate counterpoint described by music historians Kornel Michałowski and Jim Samson as "worthy of Brahms."

data.text: Chopin’s harmonic innovations likely stem from his technique in keyboard improvisation. Temperley notes that "unique harmonic effects often emerge when standard appoggiaturas or passing tones blend with the melodic figures of accompaniment" in his works, and he delays cadences by employing chords outside the home key (such as Neapolitan sixths and diminished sevenths) or through abrupt transitions to distant keys. His chord progressions prefigure the evolving tonality characteristic of later composers like Claude Debussy, akin to Chopin’s application of modal harmony.

data.text: In 1841, Léon Escudier described a Chopin recital by stating, "Chopin is the founder of both a piano school and a compositional school. Indeed, nothing rivals the lightness or sweetness with which he preludes on the piano; nor can his original, distinguished, and graceful works be compared." Chopin rejected adherence to any standard playing method, believing there was no fixed technique for excellence. His style relied heavily on highly independent finger techniques. In his "Projet de méthode," he asserted: "Mastery of fingering is crucial... We must employ the hand, wrist, forearm, and upper arm equally." He added, "Understanding a specific hand position relative to the keys allows one to effortlessly produce beautiful sounds, distinguish short from long notes, and achieve boundless dexterity." This approach resulted in Chopin's music frequently utilizing the full keyboard range, double octaves, various chord groupings, rapid repeated notes, grace notes, and contrasting rhythms (such as four against three) between hands.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: Jonathan Bellman asserts that the modern concert performance style—rooted in the late 19th- and 20th-century conservatory tradition, appropriate for large venues or recordings—conflicts with what is known about Chopin's more intimate approach to performing. The composer himself advised a student that "concerts are never real music; one must abandon the expectation of experiencing all art's most beautiful elements there." Historical accounts suggest that during performances, Chopin eschewed rigid methods sometimes wrongly attributed to him, such as consistently crescendoing to high notes. Instead, he focused on expressive phrasing, rhythmic consistency, and delicate coloring. In 1853, Berlioz noted that Chopin "has devised a type of chromatic embroidery ... with an effect so unique and intriguing that it defies description ... virtually only Chopin himself can perform this music in such a distinctive manner." Hiller observed that "what appeared as elegant embellishment in others' hands became, through his, a vibrant floral garland."

data.text: Chopin is recognized for infusing music with a novel sense of nationalism through his mazurkas and polonaises. In 1836, Schumann, reviewing Chopin's piano concertos, emphasized the composer's deep connection to Poland. He wrote, "With the Poles in profound mourning following the November 1830 uprising, their call to us artists grows stronger... Were the powerful northern ruler [Nicholas I of Russia] aware that within the simple melodies of Chopin's mazurkas lies a covert adversary, he would surely prohibit his music. Chopin's compositions are cannons concealed beneath blossoms!" A biography published in 1863 under Franz Liszt’s name (likely penned by Carolyne zu Sayn-Wittgenstein) asserts that Chopin "deserves to be placed at the forefront of premier musicians, embodying within himself the poetic essence of an entire nation."

data.text: Some contemporary scholars argue against overstating Chopin’s role as a “nationalist” or “patriotic” composer. George Golos highlights earlier Central European “nationalist” composers like Poland's Michał Kleofas Ogiński and Franciszek Lessel, who incorporated polonaise and mazurka forms into their music. Barbara Milewski posits that Chopin’s exposure to Polish music was largely through the urbanized versions found in Warsaw rather than from folk traditions, suggesting efforts by Jachimecki and others to identify genuine folk elements in his compositions lack foundation. Richard Taruskin critiques Schumann's patronizing view of Chopin’s works while noting that although Chopin felt a profound and sincere sense of Polish patriotism, he deliberately modeled his pieces on the styles of Bach, Beethoven, Schubert, and Field.

data.text: Karol Mikuli (1821–1897) and Georges Mathias, two enduring students of Chopin, were also piano instructors who imparted insights into his technique to their pupils. Influenced by Chopin’s style were other pianists and composers such as Louis Moreau Gottschalk, Édouard Wolff (1816–1880), and Pierre Zimmermann. Debussy honored Chopin by dedicating his 1915 piano Études to him; he regularly performed Chopin's pieces during his studies at the Paris Conservatoire and collaborated with publisher Jacques Durand to edit Chopin’s piano music.

data.text: The precise nature of the relationship between Tibet and the Ming dynasty of China (1368–1644) remains ambiguous. This analysis is further complicated by contemporary political disputes and applying Westphalian sovereignty concepts to a time when they were non-existent. Some scholars from Mainland China, such as Wang Jiawei and Nyima Gyaincain, argue that the Ming dynasty exercised undisputed sovereignty over Tibet, citing the issuance of titles by the Ming court to Tibetan leaders, their acceptance of these titles, and a renewal process for successors involving visits to the Ming capital. Chinese scholars also contend that Tibet has been an integral part of China since the 13th century, making it part of the Ming Empire. However, most international scholars, including Turrell V. Wylie, Melvin C. Goldstein, and Helmut Hoffman, maintain that this relationship was one of suzerainty, with Ming titles being nominal; they argue Tibet remained an independent region outside Ming control and only paid tribute until the Jiajing Emperor (1521–1566), who terminated relations with Tibet.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: Some scholars observe that Tibetan leaders during the Ming era frequently engaged in civil conflicts and independently conducted diplomacy with neighboring nations like Nepal. Others highlight the commercial dimension of the Ming-Tibetan relationship, pointing out the Ming dynasty’s need for horses for military purposes, thereby emphasizing the significance of horse trade with Tibet. Additionally, some argue that the crucial religious aspect of the Ming court's relationship with Tibetan lamas is often overlooked in contemporary studies. In an effort to rekindle the distinctive bond between the Mongol ruler Kublai Khan (r. 1260–1294) and his spiritual mentor Drogön Chögyal Phagpa (1235–1280) of the Sakya school, the Yongle Emperor (r. 1402–1424) aimed to establish both secular and religious ties with Deshin Shekpa (1384–1415), the Karmapa of the Karma Kagyu school, but these attempts did not succeed.

data.text: During the 14th century, the Ming dynasty conducted intermittent military interventions in Tibet without establishing a permanent garrison. Occasionally, Tibetans also engaged in armed resistance against these Ming incursions. The Wanli Emperor (1572–1620) endeavored to revive Sino-Tibetan relations following the Mongol-Tibetan alliance formed in 1578, which influenced the Qing dynasty's foreign policy (1644–1912) concerning their backing of the Gelug school’s Dalai Lama. By the late 16th century, the Mongols emerged as effective protectors of the Gelug Dalai Lama, bolstering their presence in the Amdo region. This led to Güshi Khan's (1582–1655) conquest of Tibet from 1637 to 1642 and the establishment of the Ganden Phodrang regime under the 5th Dalai Lama with his assistance.

data.text: In 1207, under the leadership of Mongol ruler Genghis Khan (reign: 1206–1227), the Western Xia—an ethnic Tangut state existing from 1038 to 1227—was conquered and brought under control. That same year, Genghis Khan initiated diplomatic ties with Tibet by dispatching envoys. The subjugation of the Western Xia concerned Tibetan leaders, prompting them to begin paying tribute to the Mongols. data.text: Beginning in 1236, Mongol prince Kublai was assigned a substantial appanage in North China by his superior, Ögedei Khan, who later governed as Khagan from 1260 to 1294. Karma Pakshi, the 2nd Karmapa Lama and head of the Karma Kagyu lineage of Tibetan Buddhism (1203–1283), declined Kublai's invitation. Consequently, Kublai invited Drogön Chögyal Phagpa (1235–1280), successor and nephew of Sakya Pandita, who arrived at his court in 1253. A distinctive relationship was established between Kublai and the Phagpa lama, acknowledging Kublai as a supreme sovereign in political matters and the Phagpa lama as his primary religious advisor. Additionally, Drogön Chögyal Phagpa was appointed director of the Bureau of Buddhist and Tibetan Affairs and became the ruling priest-king over Tibet, which consisted of thirteen states governed by myriarchies.

data.text: In 1368, a Han Chinese uprising called the Red Turban Rebellion overthrew the Mongol Yuan dynasty in China. Zhu Yuanzhang subsequently founded the Ming dynasty and reigned as Emperor Hongwu from 1368 to 1398. The extent of early Ming awareness regarding Tibet's internal religious conflicts remains uncertain; however, the first emperor was keen to prevent similar issues that had troubled the Tang dynasty. Rather than acknowledging the Phagmodru leader, Emperor Hongwu supported the Karmapa in the nearby Kham region and southeastern Tibet. In the winter of 1372–1373, envoys were dispatched to request that Yuan officials renew their titles with the new Ming administration.

Wylie, formerly a professor at the University of Washington, along with Li Tieh-tseng, question the credibility of the heavily censored History of Ming as a reliable source on Sino-Tibetan relations, given contemporary scholarship. data.text: Wang and Nyima contend that during the second year of the Ming dynasty, the emperor issued edicts to Tibet twice, underscoring its importance by encouraging various Tibetan tribes to recognize the authority of the Ming court. Concurrently, Mongol Prince Punala, who succeeded as ruler over parts of Tibet, journeyed to Nanjing in 1371 to present tribute and affirm his loyalty to the Ming court, bringing along a seal granted by the Yuan dynasty. They further assert that because successors of lamas bearing the title "prince" were required to visit the Ming court for title renewal—and as these lamas identified themselves as princes—the Ming court exercised comprehensive sovereignty over Tibet. Wang and Nyima explain that the Ming dynasty secured submission from ex-Yuan religious and administrative leaders in Tibetan regions by inviting former Yuan officials to assume roles at court during its early years. Consequently, they conclude that the Ming effectively assumed control over Tibetan areas previously governed by the Yuan dynasty.

data.text: Journalist and author Thomas Laird, in his book *The Story of Tibet: Conversations with the Dalai Lama*, notes that Wang and Nyima reflect the perspective of the People's Republic of China in their work *Historical Status of China’s Tibet*. However, they overlook the fact that China was incorporated into a larger non-Chinese political entity during the Mongol Yuan dynasty. Laird contends that this period should not be viewed as inherently Chinese, contrary to Wang and Nyima’s portrayal, which suggests it led directly to the Ming dynasty. He emphasizes that the ruling Mongol khans managed Tibet as separate territories rather than integrating them into China, likening the situation to how the British governed India and New Zealand independently, without merging the two nations. Laird further argues that subsequent Mongol and Tibetan interpretations of Mongolia's conquest do not depict it as a Chinese endeavor, stating these narratives never characterize the Mongol control over Tibet as inherently Chinese.

data.text: The Columbia Encyclopedia differentiates between the Yuan dynasty and other Mongol Empire khanates, such as the Ilkhanate, Chagatai Khanate, and the Golden Horde. It characterizes the Yuan dynasty as "a Mongol dynasty that governed China from 1271 to 1368, a segment of the vast empire established by the Mongols." Founded by Kublai Khan, he assumed the Chinese dynastic title Yüan in 1271. The Encyclopedia Americana refers to the Yuan dynasty as "the sequence of Mongol rulers in China," stating that the Mongols "inaugurated a Chinese-style Yüan dynasty at Khanbaliq (Beijing)." According to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Mongol leaders of the Yuan dynasty "embraced Chinese political and cultural frameworks; governing from their capital cities like Dadu, they adopted the role of Chinese emperors." However, Tibetologist Thomas Laird considers the Yuan dynasty as a non-Chinese entity, downplaying its Chinese features. The Metropolitan Museum of Art also observed that despite the gradual integration of Yuan monarchs, Mongol rulers often disregarded the literati and enforced severe policies discriminating against southern Chinese. In "Kublai Khan: His Life and Times," Rossabi notes that Kublai "established governmental bodies that mirrored or matched traditional Chinese ones" and aimed to convey through these actions his intention to emulate a Chinese ruler's manner and appearance.

data.text: The Columbia Encyclopedia differentiates the Yuan dynasty from other Mongol Empire khanates, such as the Ilkhanate, Chagatai Khanate, and the Golden Horde. It characterizes the Yuan dynasty as "a Mongol regime that governed China from 1271 to 1368, part of a larger empire established by the Mongols." Kublai Khan founded this regime in 1271 and assumed the Chinese dynastic title Yüan. The Encyclopedia Americana refers to it as "the series of Mongol rulers over China," noting the establishment of a Chinese-style Yuan dynasty at Khanbaliq (Beijing). According to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Mongol leaders of the Yuan dynasty "integrated Chinese political and cultural systems; they ruled from their capitals such as Dadu, taking on the role of Chinese emperors." Conversely, Tibetologist Thomas Laird views the Yuan dynasty as distinctively non-Chinese, downplaying its Chinese characteristics. The Metropolitan Museum of Art also points out that while Yuan rulers gradually integrated, Mongol leaders often disregarded the literati and enforced harsh policies against southern Chinese. In "Kublai Khan: His Life and Times," Rossabi notes that Kublai "established governmental frameworks reflecting or paralleling traditional Chinese ones" to present himself as a genuine Chinese emperor in style and manner.
data.label: qwen_2

data.text:
Despite this, the ethno-geographic caste hierarchy gave preference to the Mongols and other ethnicities over the Han Chinese majority. While many Han Chinese advisors held significant influence beyond their official rank, their status was less clearly defined. Kublai Khan abolished China's traditional imperial examinations, a practice not revived until Ayurbarwada Buyantu Khan's reign (1311–1320). According to Rossabi, Kublai understood that ruling China necessitated employing Chinese advisors and officials. However, he couldn't rely entirely on them as he needed to balance governing the settled Chinese civilization while preserving Mongol cultural identity and values. He was focused on both serving his Chinese subjects' interests and exploiting empire resources for personal gain, with motivations shifting between these goals throughout his reign.

Van Praag, in *The Status of Tibet*, notes that Tibetans and Mongols maintained a dual system of governance and an interdependent relationship, legitimizing the succession of Mongol khans as universal Buddhist rulers or chakravartins. He states that "Tibet remained a unique part of the Empire and was never fully integrated into it," citing instances like a licensed border market between China and Tibet during the Yuan dynasty.
data.label: gpt4

data.text:
Despite this, the ethno-geographic caste hierarchy favored Mongols and other ethnicities over the Han Chinese majority. Although numerous Han Chinese advisors wielded considerable influence beyond their official positions, their status remained ambiguous. Kublai Khan discontinued China's traditional imperial examinations, a practice not reinstated until Ayurbarwada Buyantu Khan's reign (1311–1320). As Rossabi notes, Kublai understood the necessity of employing Chinese advisors and officials to govern China effectively. Nevertheless, he couldn't depend solely on them, as it was crucial for him to balance managing the settled Chinese civilization while preserving Mongol cultural identity and values. His focus oscillated between serving his Chinese subjects' interests and leveraging empire resources for personal gain throughout his reign.

According to Van Praag in *The Status of Tibet*, Tibetans and Mongols maintained a dual governance system with an interdependent relationship, legitimizing the succession of Mongol khans as universal Buddhist rulers or chakravartins. He asserts that "Tibet remained a distinct part of the Empire and was never fully integrated into it," highlighting instances such as a licensed border market between China and Tibet during the Yuan dynasty.

data.text: Lok-Ham Chan, a history professor at the University of Washington, suggests that Changchub Gyaltsen aimed to revive the ancient Tibetan Kingdom from the Chinese Tang dynasty era, foster "nationalist sentiment" among Tibetans, and eliminate all signs of Mongol dominance. Georges Dreyfus, a religion professor at Williams College, notes that Changchub Gyaltsen adopted the administrative framework established by Songtsän Gampo (c. 605–649)—the inaugural leader who transformed Tibet into a formidable power—by reintroducing its legal and administrative structures. For instance, instead of the 13 governorships instituted by the Mongol Sakya viceroy, Changchub Gyaltsen segmented Central Tibet into districts (dzong) with district heads (dzong dpon), mandating adherence to traditional rituals and attire of Imperial Tibet. Van Praag contends that Changchub Gyaltsen sought "to restore Tibet's Imperial Age grandeur" by reestablishing secular governance, promoting "national culture and traditions," and implementing a legal code enduring into the 20th century.

data.text: Over the next month, the Yongle Emperor and his court lavished gifts upon the Karmapa. At Linggu Temple in Nanjing, he conducted religious ceremonies honoring the late parents of the Yongle Emperor. During twenty-two days of his visit, religious miracles occurred, documented on a vast scroll inscribed with the Emperor's seal in five languages. Throughout his stay, Deshin Shekpa was honored by the Yongle Emperor with the title "Great Treasure Prince of Dharma." According to Elliot Sperling, the Yongle Emperor's intention behind bestowing Deshin Shekpa with the title of "King" and commending his mystical abilities was to forge an alliance akin to that between the Mongols and the Sakya lamas. However, Deshin Shekpa declined the offer from the Yongle Emperor. Notably, this was the same title Kublai Khan had extended to the Sakya Phagpa lama, yet Deshin Shekpa persuaded the Yongle Emperor to confer it upon leaders of other Tibetan Buddhist sects instead.

data.text:
Norbu argues that Chinese Communist historians have overlooked the religious significance in the Ming-Tibetan relations, particularly regarding the fifth Karmapa and other Tibetan leaders. He explains that these meetings between lamas and the Emperor were exchanges of tribute akin to interactions between "the patron and the priest," rather than a political subordinate's tribute to a superior. Norbu highlights that the tributes consisted of Buddhist artifacts, underscoring the religious essence of these relations.

Josef Kolmaš observes that the Ming dynasty did not assert direct political authority over Tibet, satisfied with their almost entirely religious tribute interactions.

Patricia Ann Berger suggests that the Yongle Emperor's engagement and bestowing of titles upon lamas were efforts to revive the connection between China and Tibet, initially established by Yuan dynasty founder Khubilai Khan and his guru Phagpa. She further notes that later Qing emperors and their Mongol allies perceived the Yongle Emperor’s Tibetan relations as "part of a reincarnation lineage," viewing this Han Chinese emperor as another manifestation of Manjusri.

data.text: Tsai notes that following Deshin Shekpa's visit, the Yongle Emperor commissioned the creation of roads and trading posts along the upper Yangzi and Mekong Rivers to boost trade with Tibet, focusing on commodities like tea, horses, and salt. This route traversed Sichuan and crossed Shangri-La County in Yunnan. Wang and Nyima argue that this "tribute-related trade," where the Ming exchanged Chinese tea for Tibetan horses while allowing Tibetan envoys and merchants to engage with Han traders, strengthened Ming control over Tibet. Rossabi and Sperling observe that this horse-for-tea exchange predated the Ming dynasty. According to Peter C. Perdue, Wang Anshi (1021–1086) also sought horses from Inner Asia for Chinese tea due to China's insufficient production of military-ready horses, which were vital not only for cavalry but also as draft animals for supply wagons. Tibetans needed Chinese tea both for consumption and religious ceremonies. The Ming government controlled tea production through a monopoly and attempted regulation via state-supervised markets; however, these efforts failed in 1449 due to military setbacks and ecological and commercial strains on the tea regions.

data.text:
Van Praag suggests that the Ming court's establishment of diplomatic delegations with Tibet aimed primarily at securing essential horses. Wang and Nyima counter this view by asserting these were not genuine diplomatic efforts; instead, Tibetan regions were effectively governed by the Ming, as Tibetan leaders held official positions within the Ming administration. They argue that horse collection from Tibet was mandated as a "corvée" tax, implying that Tibetans were engaged in domestic tasks rather than foreign diplomacy. Sperling notes that while the Ming purchased horses in Kham and battled Tibetan tribes in Amdo, they also welcomed Tibetan embassies in Nanjing. He contends that these lama-led embassies largely aimed to facilitate commercial exchanges between their affluent retinues and Ming merchants and officials.

Kolmaš observes that although the Ming practiced a hands-off approach towards Tibet while restricting Tibetan retinue sizes, Tibetans sought a tributary relationship with the Ming due to the wealth and power it conferred. Laird highlights that Tibetans eagerly accepted Ming court invitations because the gifts received for presenting tribute far exceeded their value.

Regarding the Yongle Emperor's presents—silver items, Buddha relics, temple utensils, and monastic garments—to Tibetan and Nepalese vassals, Tsai remarks, "In his quest to attract neighboring states into the Ming sphere of influence to enhance his prestige, the Yongle Emperor was willing to incur minor expenses."

data.text: The Ming dynasty engaged in horse trade with Tibet while enforcing a ban on northern border markets as a punitive measure against Mongolian raids and to deter them from China's borders, according to Laird. After Altan Khan of the Tümed Mongols ended Oirat dominance and established peace with the Ming in 1571, he successfully convinced them to reopen these markets by 1573. This reopening helped China acquire an excess supply of horses and alleviated concerns over ongoing Mongolian raids. Laird notes that although later Mongols believed Altan compelled the Ming to regard him as a peer, Chinese historians consider him merely a loyal citizen. By 1578, Altan Khan had forged a strong Mongol-Tibetan alliance with the Gelug, which the Ming observed without interference.

data.text: During the mid-Ming dynasty, strategic discussions primarily centered on reclaiming the Ordos region, which served as a base for Mongol raids into Ming China. Sperling highlights that the relationship between the Ming and an independent Tibet was unique, marked by potential border conflicts, with the Ming's policy aiming for threat avoidance rather than subjugation. P. Christiaan Klieger suggests that Ming support for prominent Tibetan lamas aimed to stabilize frontier areas and safeguard trade routes.

data.text: Historians Luciano Petech and Sato Hisashi contend that following the collapse of the Sakya regime, the Ming dynasty implemented a "divide-and-rule" approach towards a politically fragmented Tibet. Chan suggests this might have been the deliberate strategy of the Yongle Emperor to prevent any single Tibetan sect from gaining excessive regional influence through exclusive patronage. However, Sperling does not find evidence in Chinese or Tibetan texts supporting Petech and Hisashi's theory. Norbu argues that their thesis primarily relies on a list of Ming titles given to Tibetan lamas instead of analyzing developments in both China and Tibet comparatively. Rossabi criticizes this view for overestimating the Chinese influence, noting Tibet was already divided politically when the Ming dynasty commenced. Additionally, he challenges the "divide-and-rule" theory due to the Yongle Emperor's unsuccessful efforts to establish a strong bond with the fifth Karmapa, which he intended to mirror Kublai Khan’s relationship with the Sakya Phagpa lama. Contrary to this strategy, the Yongle Emperor followed the advice of the Karmapa and distributed patronage among various Tibetan lamas instead.

Norbu argues that their thesis primarily relies on a list of Ming titles given to Tibetan lamas rather than a comparative study of developments in China and Tibet. Rossabi criticizes this viewpoint for exaggerating Chinese influence, pointing out that Tibet was already politically divided when the Ming dynasty began. He also questions the "divide-and-rule" theory due to the Yongle Emperor's unsuccessful attempts to establish a strong connection with the fifth Karmapa, which he aimed to mirror Kublai Khan’s relationship with the Sakya Phagpa lama. Contrary to this approach, the Yongle Emperor followed the advice of the Karmapa and spread patronage among various Tibetan lamas.

data.text: The Association for Asian Studies notes that there is no documented evidence indicating any contact between later Gelug leaders—Gendün Drup (1391–1474) and Gendün Gyatso (1475–1571)—and Ming China. These religious figures were primarily concerned with managing the influential secular Rinpungpa princes, who supported the Karma Kagyu lamas. Although related to the Phagmodrupa, the authority of the Rinpungpa evolved from being governors to rulers over extensive regions in Ü-Tsang. In 1498, the Rinbung prince took control of Lhasa and barred Gelug participation in key New Year ceremonies and prayers, a vital event for them. While the Karmapa and others were granted responsibilities for these New Year prayers in Lhasa, Gendún Gyatso traveled in exile seeking allies. It wasn't until 1518 that the Phagmodru ruler reclaimed Lhasa from the Rinbung, allowing the Gelug to resume conducting New Year prayers. In 1537, when the Drikung Kagyu abbot of Drigung Monastery posed a threat to Lhasa, Gendün Gyatso had to leave Drepung Monastery but later returned.

data.text: The Zhengde Emperor (reigning 1505–1521), despite opposition from the censorate, was intrigued by stories of a "living Buddha" and wished to invite this figure to the Ming capital. This individual was Mikyö Dorje, the 8th Karmapa Lama, supported by Rinpung and residing in Lhasa. The emperor's top advisors strongly advised against this invitation, citing Tibetan Buddhism as excessively heterodox. Nevertheless, disregarding objections from Grand Secretary Liang Chu, Zhengde dispatched eunuch official Liu Yun of the Palace Chancellery in 1515 with an invitation to Beijing. Liu led a fleet sourced along the Yangtze, consuming 2,835 grams (100 ounces) of silver daily for sustenance during a year-long stay in Chengdu, Sichuan, and departed later with about 1,000 cavalry troops after gathering mission gifts. However, upon delivering the invitation, the Karmapa Lama declined to leave Tibet, despite Ming efforts to compel him. He ambushed Liu Yun's camp, capturing goods and valuables while killing or injuring half of the escort. Following this debacle, Liu escaped but returned to Chengdu years later only to learn that Emperor Zhengde had passed away.

data.text: Elliot Sperling, an expert in Indian studies and director of the Tibetan Studies program at Indiana University’s Department of Central Eurasia Studies, asserts that the notion of Tibet becoming part of China in the 13th century is a recent development. He notes that early 20th-century Chinese scholars believed Tibet was not annexed by China until the Manchu Qing dynasty's invasion in the 18th century. These writers characterized Tibet as a feudal dependency rather than an integral component of China. Sperling explains this perspective, stating that "Tibet was governed within the Mongol and Manchu empires" and that "the intervening Ming dynasty had no control over Tibet." He highlights the challenges this poses for China's claim to continuous sovereignty over Tibet since the 13th century. Regarding the Tibetan view that it was never ruled by the Yuan or Qing emperors of China, Sperling argues against this by pointing out that Tibet was "subject to the rules, laws, and decisions of the Yuan and Qing rulers," noting even Tibetans acknowledged their status as subjects under these emperors.

Laird notes that Altan Khan eradicated traditional Mongol shamanistic practices and blood sacrifices. data.text: In 1565, the influential Rinbung princes were deposed by one of their ministers, Karma Tseten, who declared himself Tsangpa, "the ruler of Tsang," establishing his stronghold in Shigatse. The second heir to this inaugural Tsang monarch, Karma Phuntsok Namgyal, subsequently ruled all of Central Tibet (Ü-Tsang) from 1611–1621. However, Lhasa's leaders continued to profess loyalty both to the Phagmodru and the Gelug sects, while the Ü-Tsang king allied with the Karmapa. Hostilities escalated between the nationalist Ü-Tsang ruler and the Mongols, who protected their own Dalai Lama in Lhasa. The fourth Dalai Lama's refusal to meet the Ü-Tsang king ignited a conflict, as the latter began attacking Gelug monasteries. According to Chen, rumors about the mysterious demise of the fourth Dalai Lama suggested that the Ü-Tsang king plotted his assassination over alleged curses of illness, though Chen indicates it was likely a power struggle in feudal society. By 1618, merely two years after Yonten Gyatso's death, conflict erupted between the Gelug and Karma Kargyu factions, with the latter backed by the secular Ü-Tsang king. The ruler of Ü-Tsang killed numerous Gelugpa lamas, seized their monasteries at Drepung and Sera, and prohibited searches for a new Dalai Lama.

data.text: In 1565, Karma Tseten, a minister to the Rinbung princes, overthrew them and declared himself Tsangpa, "the ruler of Tsang," establishing his power base in Shigatse. His successor, the second heir, Karma Phuntsok Namgyal, governed all of Central Tibet (Ü-Tsang) from 1611–1621. Despite this, Lhasa's leaders remained loyal to both the Phagmodru and Gelug sects while aligning with the Karmapa under the Ü-Tsang monarch. Tensions escalated between the nationalist ruler of Ü-Tsang and the Mongols, who protected their own Dalai Lama in Lhasa. A conflict arose when the fourth Dalai Lama refused to meet the Ü-Tsang king, leading to attacks on Gelug monasteries by the latter. According to Chen, rumors regarding the mysterious death of the fourth Dalai Lama suggested that the Ü-Tsang king might have orchestrated his murder due to alleged curses of illness; however, Chen proposed it was more likely a power struggle in feudal society. By 1618, only two years after Yonten Gyatso's demise, a conflict erupted between the Gelug and Karma Kargyu factions, with the latter backed by the secular Ü-Tsang king. The ruler of Ü-Tsang killed numerous Gelugpa lamas, seized their monasteries at Drepung and Sera, and prohibited searches for a new Dalai Lama.

data.text: In 1621, following the death of the Ü-Tsang king, his young son Karma Tenkyong ascended to the throne. This succession temporarily hindered their war efforts, as Karma Tenkyong recognized six-year-old Lozang Gyatso as the new Dalai Lama. Although the Dalai Lama attempted to maintain amicable relations with the new Ü-Tsang ruler, Sonam Rapten (1595–1657), his chief steward and treasurer at Drepung conspired against the king, sparking further conflict. In 1633, Gelugpa forces, supported by several thousand Mongol followers, defeated the Ü-Tsang troops near Lhasa before peace negotiations were established. Goldstein notes that in this instance, "the Mongols played a crucial role in Tibetan affairs as the military arm of the Dalai Lama."

data.text: When an ally of the Ü-Tsang ruler again threatened to destroy the Gelugpas, the fifth Dalai Lama, Lozang Gyatso, sought assistance from Mongol prince Güshi Khan (1582–1655) of the Khoshut tribe. At that time, Güshi Khan was on a pilgrimage to Lhasa and accepted his role as protector. Between 1637 and 1640, he vanquished the Gelugpas' adversaries in Amdo and Kham regions while relocating his tribe entirely into Amdo. Sonam Chöpel advised Güshi Khan to attack the Ü-Tsang king's stronghold at Shigatse, a plan which he embraced with support from Gelug monks and allies. After besieging Shigatse for a year, the Ü-Tsang forces capitulated in 1642. Subsequently, Güshi Khan captured and executed Karma Tenkyong, the ruler of Ü-Tsang and King of Tibet.

data.text:
Shortly after his triumph in Ü-Tsang, Güshi Khan hosted a welcoming ceremony for Lozang Gyatso upon his arrival near Shigatse, presenting Tibet's conquest as a tribute to the Dalai Lama. In another ceremony within Shigatse fortress's main hall, Güshi Khan enthroned the Dalai Lama as Tibet's leader but delegated actual governance to regent Sonam Chöpel. While Goldstein notes that Güshi Khan granted the Dalai Lama "supreme authority," he also received the title of 'King of Tibet,' spending summers north of Lhasa and winters in Lhasa itself. Van Praag mentions that at this time, although Güshi Khan controlled the armed forces, he acknowledged his subordinate status to the Dalai Lama.

Rawski observes that during the early phase of his dual secular and religious reign, the Dalai Lama shared power with both his regent and Güshi Khan. However, Rawski asserts that the Dalai Lama later "expanded his authority by embodying Avalokiteśvara through ritual performances," constructing the Potala Palace on sacred sites, and emphasizing lineage reincarnation via written biographies.

According to Goldstein, the regime of Güshi Khan and the Dalai Lama oppressed the Karma Kagyu sect by seizing their wealth and properties, converting their monasteries into Gelug establishments. Rawski indicates that Mongol support enabled the Gelugpas to overshadow other Tibetan religious factions.

data.text:
In 1644, the Chinese Ming dynasty fell due to Li Zicheng's (1606–1645) rebellion. His brief Shun dynasty was subsequently overthrown by the Manchu invasion with Han Chinese general Wu Sangui (1612–1678). China Daily reports that when the Qing dynasty succeeded the Ming, it simply "strengthened administration in Tibet." However, Kolmaš notes that the Dalai Lama was astute in observing events in China and accepted a Manchu invitation in 1640 to send envoys to their capital at Mukden by 1642, even before the Ming's collapse.

Dawa Norbu, William Rockhill, and George N. Patterson indicate that when the Qing dynasty's Shunzhi Emperor (r. 1644–1661) invited the fifth Dalai Lama Lozang Gyatso to Beijing in 1652, he treated him as Tibet’s independent sovereign. Patterson suggests this was a strategic move by Shunzhi to forge an alliance with Tibet, eventually facilitating Manchu control over Mongolia.

Goldstein asserts that during their meeting, the Qing emperor recognized the Dalai Lama's significant influence due to his alliances with Mongol tribes, some of which were enemies of the Qing. Van Praag mentions that Tibet and the Dalai Lama’s authority were acknowledged by the "Manchu Emperor, Mongolian Khans and Princes, and rulers of Ladakh, Nepal, India, Bhutan, and Sikkim."

data.text:
Although introduced in 2001, the iPod's high price and compatibility exclusively with Macs resulted in sluggish sales until 2004. Originating from Apple’s “digital hub” initiative, this line emerged as the company ventured into software development for an expanding market of personal digital devices. While digital cameras, camcorders, and organizers already enjoyed substantial mainstream markets, Apple identified existing music players as either overly large or too small and ineffective, with user interfaces that were "unbelievably awful." Consequently, Apple opted to design its own solution.

Under the direction of CEO Steve Jobs, hardware engineering chief Jon Rubinstein led a team comprising engineers Tony Fadell and Michael Dhuey, along with design engineer Sir Jonathan Ive. Prior to this project, Rubinstein had secured rights to a Toshiba disk drive during an encounter with an Apple supplier in Japan and had figured out how the screen, battery, and other crucial components would function. The device's aesthetic drew inspiration from the 1958 Braun T3 transistor radio designed by Dieter Rams, while its wheel-based interface was influenced by Bang & Olufsen’s BeoCom 6000 telephone.

Developed in less than a year, the iPod, dubbed “the Walkman of the twenty-first century,” was unveiled on October 23, 2001. Jobs introduced it as a Mac-compatible device featuring a 5 GB hard drive that could store "1,000 songs in your pocket."
data.label: gpt4

data.text: Apple did not fully develop the iPod software internally; instead, they utilized PortalPlayer's reference platform based on two ARM cores. This platform featured basic software running on a commercial microkernel embedded operating system. Prior to this, PortalPlayer had been developing an MP3 player branded by IBM with Bluetooth headphones. Apple engaged another company, Pixo, to assist in designing and implementing the user interface under Steve Jobs' direct supervision. As development continued, Apple refined the software's aesthetics. Starting with the iPod Mini, the Chicago font was replaced by Espy Sans. Subsequent models transitioned again to Podium Sans—a font akin to Apple's corporate typeface, Myriad. Models featuring color displays later incorporated Mac OS X themes such as Aqua progress bars and brushed metal resembling a combination lock. In 2007, with the launch of the sixth-generation iPod Classic and third-generation iPod Nano, Apple updated the interface by switching the font to Helvetica and dividing the screen; menus appeared on the left while album artwork, photos, or videos were shown on the right, depending on the selected content.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: In September 2007, amidst a lawsuit involving patent holding company Burst.com, Apple highlighted a patent for a comparable device that originated in 1979. data.text: The name iPod originated from a suggestion by Vinnie Chieco, a freelance copywriter, who, along with others, was consulted by Apple on how to market the new player. Upon viewing a prototype, Chieco drew inspiration from the movie "2001: A Space Odyssey," specifically recalling the line "Open the pod bay door, Hal!" and likened this to the relationship between the Discovery One's white EVA Pods and a personal computer paired with an independent music player. Apple discovered that the trademark was already in use by Joseph N. Grasso of New Jersey, who had filed it with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) for Internet kiosks in July 2000. Although public demonstrations of the first iPod kiosks occurred in New Jersey in March 1998 and commercial deployment began in January 2000, they were reportedly discontinued by 2001. The USPTO registered the trademark in November 2003, and Grasso later assigned it to Apple Computer, Inc. in 2005.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: The third-generation iPod exhibited poor bass performance in audio tests. This issue stemmed from the combination of small DC-blocking capacitors and the low impedance typical of most consumer headphones, which together created a high-pass filter that diminished low-frequency bass output. The fourth-generation iPods used similar capacitors. However, using high-impedance headphones mitigates this problem, and it becomes non-existent when driving high-impedance (line-level) loads like an external headphone amplifier. In contrast, the first-generation iPod Shuffle employs a dual-transistor output stage instead of a single capacitor-coupled output, thus avoiding any bass response reduction regardless of the load.
data.label: gpt4

On the other hand, the first-generation iPod Shuffle uses a dual-transistor output stage instead of a single capacitor-coupled output, thus maintaining consistent bass response regardless of the load type.

data.text: The iPod series supports multiple audio file formats, including MP3, AAC/M4A, Protected AAC, AIFF, WAV, Audible audiobooks, and Apple Lossless. The iPod photo expanded its capabilities to display JPEG, BMP, GIF, TIFF, and PNG image files. Fifth and sixth generation iPod Classics, along with the third-generation iPod Nano, can also play MPEG-4 (H.264/MPEG-4 AVC) and QuickTime video formats, though there are limitations regarding video dimensions, encoding methods, and data rates. Initially, iPod software was compatible only with Mac OS; however, support for Microsoft Windows started with the second-generation model. Unlike many other media players, Apple does not support Microsoft's WMA audio format. Nevertheless, a converter for DRM-free WMA files is available in the Windows version of iTunes. MIDI files are unsupported but can be converted to audio using the "Advanced" menu in iTunes. Alternative open-source formats like Ogg Vorbis and FLAC require custom firmware installation on an iPod (e.g., Rockbox) for support.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: During installation, an iPod is linked to a single host computer. Each connection of an iPod to this computer allows iTunes to synchronize either the entire music collection or specific playlists, either automatically or manually. Users can set song ratings on their iPods and later synchronize these with the iTunes library, or vice versa. If configured for manual sync rather than automatic, users may access, play, and add music using a second computer; however, any changes will be undone when the device is connected to and synced with the primary computer's library. To automatically sync music from another computer, an iPod’s existing library must be completely overwritten by the new computer's library.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: iPods equipped with color displays utilize anti-aliased graphics and text, accompanied by sliding animations. All iPod models, except the 3rd-generation iPod Shuffle, the 6th and 7th generation iPod Nano, and iPod Touch, feature five buttons. In later generations, these buttons are integrated into the click wheel, providing a clean, minimalist interface. The buttons manage basic functions such as menu navigation, play, pause, next track, and previous track. Additional operations like scrolling through menus and adjusting volume are executed by rotating the click wheel. The 3rd-generation iPod Shuffle lacks controls on the device itself; instead, it includes a small control panel on the earphone cable with buttons for volume adjustment and functions like play/pause and track navigation. Unlike other models, the iPod Touch does not have a click-wheel but utilizes a 3.5-inch touch screen along with a home button and sleep/wake button. The second and third generations also include volume-up and -down buttons. Its user interface mirrors that of the iPhone, with the exception of lacking a phone application. Both devices operate on iOS.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: When introduced, purchased audio files utilized the AAC format with encryption through the FairPlay DRM system. Up to five authorized computers and an unlimited number of iPods were permitted to play these files. Converting files into an audio CD via iTunes and then re-importing would result in music without DRM protection. Third-party software could also remove the DRM. However, EMI, following a deal with Apple, began offering DRM-free songs at higher quality under "iTunes Plus" on the iTunes Store. While individual tracks cost US$1.29—30¢ more than standard DRM-protected ones—complete albums were available for US$9.99, matching the price of DRM-encoded albums. On October 17, 2007, Apple reduced the price of iTunes Plus songs to US$0.99 per track, aligning with DRM-protected tracks' cost. On January 6, 2009, Apple announced that DRM had been removed from 80% of its music catalog and would be eliminated entirely by April 2009.

data.text: iPods have faced criticism for their purported short lifespan and delicate hard drives. A 2005 survey on MacInTouch revealed an average failure rate of 13.7% within the iPod lineup, though respondent feedback suggested that "the actual failure rate might be lower than reported." The study found varying durability among models; specifically, those with hard drives typically had failure rates exceeding 20%, whereas those equipped with flash memory fell below a 10% failure rate. Later in 2005, numerous users reported the first-generation iPod Nano's surface scratching easily, which compromised screen usability. This led to a class action lawsuit. Apple initially deemed it a minor defect but subsequently began distributing protective sleeves for these devices.

data.text: All iPods, except for the iPod Touch, can operate in "disk mode" to function as mass storage devices for data files; however, this may not be their default setting. For the iPod Touch, special software is required to enable this feature. When an iPod is formatted on a Mac OS computer, it adopts the HFS+ file system format, allowing it to serve as a boot disk for a Mac. On Windows, it uses the FAT32 format. The introduction of the Windows-compatible iPod shifted the default file system across the iPod line from HFS+ to FAT32, though reformatting to either file system is possible (except for the iPod Shuffle, which exclusively supports FAT32). Typically, if a new iPod (excluding the iPod Shuffle) is first connected to a Windows computer, it will use FAT32. Conversely, when initially connected to a Mac running macOS, it will employ HFS+.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess is an action-adventure game emphasizing combat, exploration, and item collection. It employs the fundamental control scheme first introduced in Ocarina of Time, featuring context-sensitive action buttons and L-targeting (Z-targeting on the Wii). This system enables players to maintain focus on enemies or significant objects while navigating and engaging in battle. Link can walk, run, attack, and automatically jump when approaching ledges. In combat, he uses a sword and shield, supported by secondary weapons such as bows and arrows, boomerangs, bombs, and the Clawshot, which is akin to the Hookshot from earlier Zelda games. When utilizing L-targeting, Link can fire projectile-based weapons at targets without manual aiming.

data.text: Upon entering the Twilight Realm, a corrupting void within Hyrule, Link transforms into a wolf. Eventually, he gains the ability to switch between his human form and his wolf form at will. As a wolf, Link can no longer wield his sword or shield nor use secondary items; instead, he relies on biting for attacks and dodging as his primary defense mechanism. However, Wolf Link possesses several significant benefits: he moves more swiftly than in his human form (though Epona remains the fastest mode of transport), is capable of digging to create new paths and unearth hidden items, and has enhanced senses, including the ability to follow scent trails. Additionally, he carries Midna, a diminutive imp-like creature who provides hints, employs an energy field for combat, assists in long-distance jumps, and eventually enables Link to "warp" to various predetermined locations across the overworld. Utilizing Wolf Link's heightened senses, players can observe and hear the wandering spirits of those impacted by the Twilight, as well as hunt enemy ghosts known as Poes.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: "Twilight Princess" is set several centuries after "Ocarina of Time" and "Majora’s Mask," beginning with a young man named Link working as a ranch hand in Ordon Village. One day, Bulblins attack the village, kidnapping its children while Link gives chase until he reaches a wall of Twilight. A Shadow Beast drags him past this barrier into the Realm of Twilight, where he is transformed into a wolf and imprisoned. An imp-like Twilight being named Midna soon frees him; despite her dislike for Link, she agrees to assist him on the condition that he obeys her unconditionally. She leads him to Princess Zelda, who explains that Zant, the King of the Twilight, has stolen the light from three of the four Light Spirits and conquered Hyrule. To save Hyrule, Link must first restore the Light Spirits by entering the Twilight-covered areas as a wolf and recover their lost light using the "Tears of Light." By collecting all necessary Tears for each area, he can restore that area’s Light Spirit. As this is accomplished, the Light Spirits transform him back into his human form.

data.text:
During this period, Link assists Midna in locating the Fused Shadows—fragments of a relic imbued with potent dark magic. In exchange, she aids him in rescuing Ordon Village's children and supports the monkeys of Faron, Eldin's Gorons, and Lanayru's Zoras. Once Link has restored the Light Spirits and Midna collects all the Fused Shadows, they are ambushed by Zant. After taking the fragments from Midna, she mocks him for exploiting his tribe's magic; however, Zant discloses that he draws power from a different source. He uses this power to transform Link back into a wolf before leaving Midna in Hyrule to perish under the world’s light.

When Link brings an injured Midna to Zelda, he discovers that the Master Sword is necessary for his return to human form. Zelda sacrifices herself to use her powers to heal Midna and then vanishes mysteriously. Moved by Zelda's sacrifice, Midna starts to value Link more deeply and becomes concerned about the fate of the light world.

data.text: Upon acquiring the Master Sword, Link is purged of the magic binding him to his wolf form and gains possession of the Shadow Crystal. This allows him to transform between forms at will. Guided by Midna, he journeys to the Mirror of Twilight in the depths of the Gerudo Desert—the sole portal linking the Twilight Realm with Hyrule—only to find it shattered. The Sages explain that Zant attempted its destruction but only succeeded in fragmenting it; only the rightful Twili ruler can fully obliterate the mirror. They also disclose they used this artifact a century ago to exile Ganondorf, the Gerudo leader who tried to seize the Triforce, after failing to execute him. With aid from an underground resistance group encountered in Castle Town, Link and Midna embark on a quest to recover the mirror's fragments, overcoming those corrupted by it. Upon restoring the portal, it is revealed that Midna is Hyrule's rightful Twilight Realm sovereign, dethroned by Zant through his curse transforming her into her current state. In their confrontation with Zant, Link and Midna uncover that Zant’s rise to power was enabled by an alliance he forged with Ganondorf, who sought Zant’s help in conquering Hyrule. After defeating Zant, although Midna retrieves the Fused Shadows, she destroys him upon realizing only Ganondorf's demise can lift her curse.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: In 2003, Nintendo revealed plans for a new Legend of Zelda game for the GameCube, developed by the team behind the cel-shaded The Wind Waker. At the subsequent year's Game Developers Conference, director Eiji Aonuma inadvertently disclosed that a sequel was in progress under the working title The Wind Waker 2, intended to use a similar graphical style as its predecessor. Nintendo of America informed Aonuma that sluggish sales of The Wind Waker in North America were due to its cartoonish appearance, which suggested it was aimed at a younger audience. Concerned about replicating this issue with the sequel, Aonuma discussed his desire with producer Shigeru Miyamoto to develop a more realistic Zelda game appealing to the North American market. Though hesitant about changing only the game's presentation, Miyamoto recommended focusing on gameplay innovations. He advised Aonuma to explore features not possible in Ocarina of Time, particularly emphasizing horseback combat.

data.text: Previous entries in the Zelda series have explored themes of two distinct yet interconnected worlds. In *A Link to the Past*, players navigate between a "Light World" and a "Dark World"; similarly, in both *Ocarina of Time* and *Oracle of Ages*, Link journeys through different time periods. The development team aimed to incorporate this concept into their latest release. It was proposed that Link transforms into a wolf, echoing his change into a rabbit in the Dark World of *A Link to the Past*. Aonuma initially conceived the game's story, which later underwent revisions by scenario writers Mitsuhiro Takano and Aya Kyogoku. Takano penned the script for story scenes, while Kyogoku and Takayuki Ikkaku crafted the in-game dialogue. During this time, Aonuma focused on directing *The Minish Cap* for the Game Boy Advance, leaving his team to progress with the new concept. Upon his return, he discovered that the Twilight Princess team faced challenges. The focus on parallel worlds and wolf transformation rendered Link's character implausible. Additionally, Aonuma observed that the gameplay lacked the innovative quality found in *Phantom Hourglass*, which utilized touch controls for the Nintendo DS. Concurrently, development of the Wii, codenamed "Revolution," was underway. Miyamoto suggested that the Wii Remote's pointing feature would be ideal for targeting arrows in Zelda and recommended its use to Aonuma.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: Aonuma initially planned a Zelda game for what became known as the Wii, assuming he must first finish Twilight Princess. His team developed a pointing-based interface for using the bow and arrow, leading Aonuma to discover that aiming directly at the screen provided a fresh gaming experience akin to Phantom Hourglass on DS. Although confident in this approach, Aonuma was concerned about fans expecting a GameCube release; creating dual versions would delay the promised 2005 launch, potentially disappointing them further. Satoru Iwata believed offering both versions ultimately satisfied users, despite the wait for completion. Consequently, Aonuma proceeded with developing both versions concurrently.

data.text:
The team developed a Wii control scheme by modifying camera control and combat mechanics for the new interface. They created a prototype using a swinging gesture to maneuver the sword from a first-person perspective; however, it failed to showcase the full range of Link's movements. Upon restoring the third-person view, Aonuma found it odd to use the right hand on the Wii Remote to swing the sword in Link’s left hand, leading to the entire map being mirrored for the Wii version.

Details about Wii controls emerged in December 2005 when NGC Magazine reported that a GameCube copy of Twilight Princess could be played with a Revolution controller. Miyamoto confirmed this functionality during an interview with Nintendo of Europe, which Time subsequently covered. However, GameCube support for the Wii controller was omitted from its release. At E3 2006, Nintendo announced both versions would launch simultaneously with the Wii, including a playable version at the event.

Eventually, the GameCube release was delayed by a month following the Wii's launch.
data.label: gpt4

data.text:
Nintendo staff reported that demo participants expressed concerns about the challenging control scheme. Aonuma recognized that his team had designed Wii controls with an expectation for users to adjust rather than ensuring they were intuitive and user-friendly. Consequently, he collaborated with Miyamoto to redesign the controls, emphasizing comfort and ease of use. 

The camera mechanics underwent revision, and item controls were altered to prevent unintentional button presses. Additionally, the revamped item system necessitated using a button previously dedicated to the sword function. To address this, sword operations reverted to gesture-based commands—a feature E3 attendees had expressed interest in seeing. This change reintroduced the challenge of managing a left-handed attack with right-handed swings. Time constraints before release prevented altering Link's character model, prompting the team to mirror the entire game environment instead.

As a result, Link became right-handed, and directional references such as "east" and "west" were reversed. The GameCube version retained its original orientation. The Twilight Princess player’s guide primarily covers the Wii adaptation but includes mirrored maps in the back section for GameCube users.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: The score of the game was crafted by Toru Minegishi and Asuka Ohta, with series regular Koji Kondo overseeing sound supervision. In "Twilight Princess," Minegishi managed both composition and sound design, creating all field and dungeon music under Kondo's guidance. For promotional trailers, three pieces were composed by different musicians; Mahito Yokota and Kondo each contributed two of these works. Michiru Ōshima arranged the compositions for an orchestra, which was then performed by a group led by conductor Yasuzo Takemoto. Eventually, Kondo's composition was selected as the music for the E3 2005 trailer and the demo video following the game's title screen.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: Media inquiries at the trade show prompted Kondo to explore using orchestral music for additional game tracks, an idea strengthened by his affinity for live instruments. Initially, he planned for a 50-person orchestra during action scenes and a string quartet for more "lyrical moments," though ultimately sequenced music was utilized instead. Kondo later explained that the limited interactivity of orchestral music was a primary factor in this choice. The game's soundtrack, available in both six- and seven-track versions, was released on November 19, 2006, as part of a Nintendo Power promotion, bundled with replicas of the Master Sword and Hylian Shield.
data.label: gpt4

data.text: Following the identification of a buffer overflow flaw in the Wii's Twilight Princess game, an exploit named "Twilight Hack" was created to execute custom code from a Secure Digital (SD) card on the console. A well-crafted save file would prompt the game to load unsigned code, potentially comprising Executable and Linkable Format (ELF) programs and homebrew Wii applications. The Wii Menu versions 3.3 and 3.4 initially blocked copying of these exploited save files onto the system until methods to bypass this restriction were uncovered; subsequently, version 4.0 of the Wii Menu addressed and fixed the vulnerability.
data.label: gpt4

A carefully crafted save file would lead the game to load unsigned code, potentially including Executable and Linkable Format (ELF) programs and homebrew applications. Initially, Wii Menu versions 3.3 and 3.4 prevented copying these compromised save files to the system until ways to circumvent this restriction were found. Later, version 4.0 of the Wii Menu rectified the security flaw.

data.text: A buffer overflow vulnerability was identified in "Twilight Princess" for the Wii, leading to the development of an exploit known as "Twilight Hack," which allowed custom code execution from a Secure Digital (SD) card on the console. By using a specially crafted save file, the game could load unsigned code, potentially including Executable and Linkable Format (ELF) programs and homebrew applications. Initially, Wii Menu versions 3.3 and 3.4 restricted copying these compromised save files to the system, but methods were eventually discovered to bypass this limitation. Subsequently, version 4.0 of the Wii Menu addressed and fixed this security vulnerability.

data.text: Twilight Princess was met with widespread critical praise and achieved significant commercial success upon its release. It garnered perfect ratings from prominent publications including 1UP.com, Computer and Video Games, Electronic Gaming Monthly, Game Informer, GamesRadar, and GameSpy. On the review aggregators GameRankings and Metacritic, it received average scores of 95% and 95 for the Wii version, while the GameCube version achieved scores of 95% and 96. GameTrailers lauded it as one of the greatest games ever developed in their review.

data.text: Upon its release, many critics, including those from 1UP.com, Computer and Video Games, Electronic Gaming Monthly, Game Informer, GamesRadar, IGN, and The Washington Post, hailed Twilight Princess as potentially the finest Zelda game ever. Game Informer described it as "so inventive that it matches Hollywood's best offerings." GamesRadar extolled the game, calling it deserving of "the absolute highest recommendation." Cubed3 celebrated Twilight Princess as "the ultimate video game experience." While its graphics received praise for their art style and animation, the title was developed for the technically inferior GameCube. Both IGN and GameSpy noted issues like blurry textures and low-resolution characters. Nevertheless, Computer and Video Games lauded the game's atmosphere as superior to all prior Zelda titles, with Twilight Princess's Hyrule hailed as its best iteration. PALGN commended the cinematics, stating that "the cutscenes are unparalleled in Zelda games." Concerning the Wii version, GameSpot’s Jeff Gerstmann remarked that the Wii controls seemed "tacked-on," yet 1UP.com praised the remote-swinging sword mechanics as "the most impressive in the series." Gaming Nexus acclaimed Twilight Princess's soundtrack as the best of its generation, although IGN criticized its MIDI-formatted music for lacking "the punch and crispness" of orchestral versions. Hyper's Javier Glickman appreciated the game for its "extensive quests, excellent Wii controls, and flexible save feature."
data.label: gpt4

data.text: The GameCube version of Twilight Princess garnered accolades from IGN for Best Artistic Design, Best Original Score, and Best Use of Sound. Both IGN and Nintendo Power honored it with awards for Best Graphics and Best Story. It received Game of the Year recognition from GameTrailers, 1UP.com, Electronic Gaming Monthly, Game Informer, Games Radar, GameSpy, Spacey Awards, X-Play, and Nintendo Power. The Game Critics Awards, X-Play, IGN, GameTrailers, 1UP.com, and Nintendo Power awarded it Best Adventure Game. Additionally, the Game Critics Awards and GameSpy acclaimed it as the Best Console Game. In Official Nintendo Magazine's list of the 100 Greatest Nintendo Games of All Time, it ranked 16th. IGN placed it as the fourth-best Wii game, while Nintendo Power ranked it third among games released on a Nintendo system in the 2000s.

data.text: In PAL territories—encompassing most of Africa, Asia, Europe, and Oceania—"Twilight Princess" holds the title of best-selling game in the Zelda series. During its debut week, it was bundled with three out of every four Wii consoles purchased. As of March 31, 2011, the game had sold 5.82 million copies on the Wii, and by March 31, 2007, it had reached sales of 1.32 million units on the GameCube.

data.text: "Spectre" (2015) is the twenty-fourth installment in the James Bond series produced by Eon Productions. It stars Daniel Craig for his fourth time as James Bond, alongside Christoph Waltz portraying Ernst Stavro Blofeld, marking the character's return to the franchise. Directed by Sam Mendes for his second Bond film after "Skyfall," it was written by John Logan, Neal Purvis, Robert Wade, and Jez Butterworth. Distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Columbia Pictures, "Spectre" has an estimated budget of $245 million, making it the most costly James Bond movie to date and one of the priciest films ever produced.
