data.text: During the era of intense internal conflicts for supremacy among the Northern Christian kingdoms, the County of Portugal comprised the southern part of the Kingdom of Galicia. At times, the Kingdom of Galicia operated independently, though it predominantly formed a significant portion of the Kingdom of León. Throughout this period, the inhabitants of the County of Portugal, identifying as Galicians, endeavored to preserve Galician autonomy with its unique language and culture (Galician-Portuguese) against Leonese influence whenever the status of the Kingdom of Galicia shifted in relation to the Kingdom of León. Consequently, political divisions led to a loss of unity for Galician-Portuguese when the County of Portugal separated from the Kingdom of Galicia—a dependent kingdom of León—to establish the Kingdom of Portugal. As a result, the Galician and Portuguese variants of the language began diverging as they followed separate evolutionary paths. This divergence started when the Kingdom of León united with the Kingdom of Castile, leading to the gradual influence—and eventual attempts to replace—the Galician Language by the Castilian Language (known as Spanish). A similar process occurred with the Astur-Leonese Language, reducing its presence or completely replacing it by Castilian.

data.text: In 1738, Sebastião José de Carvalho e Melo, the 1st Marquis of Pombal, embarked on his diplomatic career as the Portuguese Ambassador to London before serving in Vienna. Archduchess Maria Anne Josefa of Austria, Queen consort of Portugal, favored Melo; following his first wife's death, she facilitated his second marriage to a daughter of Austrian Field Marshal Leopold Josef, Count von Daun. However, King John V of Portugal was displeased and recalled Melo in 1749. After John V's death the subsequent year, his son, Joseph I, ascended to the throne as king. Unlike his father, Joseph I admired de Melo, and with the Queen Mother's endorsement, appointed him Minister of Foreign Affairs.

data.text: Portugal, officially known as the Portuguese Republic (in Portuguese: República Portuguesa), is situated on the Iberian Peninsula in Southwestern Europe. It stands as mainland Europe's westernmost nation, bordered by the Atlantic Ocean to its west and south, and by Spain to its north and east. The border between Portugal and Spain stretches 1,214 km (754 mi) and holds the distinction of being the longest continuous boundary within the European Union. Additionally, Portugal encompasses the autonomous regions of the Azores and Madeira archipelagos in the Atlantic Ocean, each with their own regional governments.

data.text: The territory now known as Portugal has experienced continuous settlement and conflict since prehistoric times. Initially inhabited by the Celts and Romans, it was later occupied by the Visigoths and Suebi Germanic peoples before falling under Moorish control. The Christian Reconquista eventually expelled these Muslim forces from the region. By 1139, Portugal emerged as an independent kingdom separate from León. During the 15th and 16th centuries, Portugal spearheaded the Age of Discovery, extending Western influence and establishing a global empire. As a result, it became a leading economic, political, and military power worldwide.

data.text: Portugal experienced a significant decline in wealth and status following the devastation of Lisbon by an earthquake in 1755, its occupation during the Napoleonic Wars, and Brazil's independence in 1822 as its most prosperous colony. The monarchy was overthrown by the 1910 revolution, leading to the establishment of the democratic yet unstable Portuguese First Republic, which was eventually replaced by the authoritarian "Estado Novo" regime. Democracy was reinstated after the Portuguese Colonial War and the Carnation Revolution in 1974. Subsequently, Portugal granted independence to all its colonies, except Macau, which was returned to China in 1999. This event concluded the longest-lasting European colonial empire, leaving a lasting cultural and architectural impact worldwide and a legacy of over 250 million Portuguese speakers today.

data.text: The formative history of Portugal is intertwined with that of the broader Iberian Peninsula in southwestern Europe. The name "Portugal" stems from the combined Romano-Celtic term Portus Cale. This region was initially inhabited by Pre-Celts and Celts, giving rise to groups such as the Gallaeci, Lusitanians, Celtici, and Cynetes. It later encountered Phoenicians and Carthaginians before becoming part of the Roman Republic's territories known as Lusitania and a portion of Gallaecia from 45 BC until 298 AD. Subsequently, it was settled again by the Suebi, Buri, and Visigoths, eventually falling under Moorish control. Additionally, remnants of a 5th-century Alan settlement have been discovered in areas such as Alenquer (formerly known as Alankerk, meaning "church of the Alan people"), Coimbra, and Lisbon.

data.text: In 27 BC, Lusitania was designated as a Roman province. Subsequently, Gallaecia emerged as a northern province of Lusitania, with its capital at Bracara Augusta, now known as Braga. Across modern Portugal, numerous ruins of castros (hill forts) and remnants of the Castro culture can still be observed. Additionally, various Roman sites are dispersed throughout present-day Portugal, some featuring significant urban remains like Conímbriga and Mirobriga. Conímbriga stands out not only as one of the largest Roman settlements in Portugal but is also recognized as a National Monument. Situated 16 km from Coimbra (anciently called Aeminium), it houses a museum that exhibits artifacts uncovered by archaeologists during excavations.

data.text: In just a few months, the Umayyad Caliphate triumphed over the Visigoths and began rapid expansion across the peninsula. Starting in 711, what is now Portugal was incorporated into the extensive Umayyad Caliphate of Damascus, which spanned from the Indus River in present-day Pakistan to southern France until its downfall in 750. In that year, the western part of the empire declared independence under Abd-ar-Rahman I, forming the Emirate of Córdoba. Nearly two centuries later, in 929, the Emirate was elevated to the Caliphate of Córdoba, which eventually dissolved a century thereafter, in 1031, into twenty-three smaller kingdoms known as the Taifa kingdoms.

data.text: The rulers of the taifas each declared themselves Emir of their respective provinces and initiated diplomatic ties with the northern Christian kingdoms. A significant portion of Portugal came under the control of the Taifa of Badajoz led by the Aftasid Dynasty, while after a brief existence of an ephemeral Taifa of Lisbon in 1022, it became part of the Taifa of Seville governed by the Abbadids poets. The era of the taifas concluded with the Almoravids' conquest from Morocco in 1086, marked by their decisive triumph at the Battle of Sagrajas. This was followed a century later, after a second period of taifas, by the rise of the Almohads from Marrakesh in 1147.

data.text: The region's Muslim population primarily comprised native Iberians who converted to Islam, known as Muwallad or Muladi, alongside a smaller number of Berbers and Arabs. The Arab contingent mainly consisted of Omani noblemen; though few in number, they formed the elite class. Berbers, originally from North Africa's Atlas and Rif mountains, were predominantly nomadic. In Portugal, the relatively small Muslim community, referred to as "Moors," resided primarily in the Algarve region and south of the Tagus River. Today, around 800 Portuguese words have Arabic origins. Muslims were expelled from Portugal three centuries before their expulsion from neighboring Spain, a fact reflected in both Portuguese culture and language, which are predominantly Celtiberian and Vulgar Latin in origin.

data.text: In the year preceding Alfonso III "the Great" of Asturias' death, three of his sons rebelled against him, compelling him to abdicate and divide the kingdom among themselves. García, the eldest son, ascended as king of León, while Ordoño ruled over Galicia. Fruela received control of Asturias with Oviedo as its capital. Alfonso passed away in Zamora, likely in 910. His former realm was later reunited when García died without an heir and his kingdom of León transferred to Ordoño. After Ordoño's death—his children were too young to inherit—the crown unified under Fruela's rule. However, Fruela's subsequent passing the following year sparked prolonged internal conflicts, leading to over a century of unstable succession. This period persisted until it was absorbed into the Kingdom of Castile in 1230 when Ferdinand III became joint monarch of both kingdoms, aiming to prevent dynastic disputes and fortify the Christian realms against potential Muslim dominance in the Iberian Peninsula. This strategy also aimed to advance the Reconquista by Christian forces.

Following Ordoño's death—since his children were too young to inherit—the crown unified under Fruela. García ascended as king of León, Ordoño took charge of Galicia, and Fruela assumed control of Asturias with Oviedo as its capital. Alfonso passed away in Zamora around 910. The kingdom was subsequently reunified following García's death without an heir, leading to the transfer of León to Ordoño. After Ordoño's demise, his young children were deemed too immature to inherit, resulting in the crown uniting under Fruela. However, upon Fruela's death the subsequent year, prolonged internal strife emerged, causing over a century of unstable succession. This period of instability persisted until 1230 when the kingdom was integrated into Castile; Ferdinand III became co-sovereign of both realms, seeking to prevent dynastic disputes and fortify Christian territories against potential Muslim dominance in Iberia. His strategy also bolstered the advance of the Reconquista by Christian forces.

data.text: In 1348 and 1349, like much of Europe, Portugal was ravaged by the Black Death. In 1373, an alliance with England was forged, marking what is considered the world's longest-standing partnership. This alliance has continually served both nations' interests throughout history and is often viewed as a precursor to NATO. Over time, it extended beyond geopolitical and military cooperation—aimed at safeguarding mutual interests in Africa, the Americas, and Asia against French, Spanish, and Dutch adversaries—to foster enduring trade and cultural connections between these longstanding European allies. The English influence remains particularly evident in the Oporto region today.

data.text: The Portuguese government and military effectively resisted decolonization of their overseas territories until April 1974. During that month, a bloodless left-wing coup in Lisbon, known as the Carnation Revolution, paved the way for these territories' independence in Africa and Asia, alongside restoring democracy after two years under PREC (Processo Revolucionário Em Curso). This transitional period was marked by social unrest and clashes between leftist and rightist political groups. The withdrawal from overseas territories and acceptance of their independence terms by Portuguese officials led to a large-scale departure of Portuguese citizens from African regions, primarily from Angola and Mozambique, culminating in the formation of independent states in 1975.

data.text: Portugal exhibits a Mediterranean climate, classified as Csa in the south, interior, and Douro region; Csb in northern and central Portugal along with coastal Alentejo; mixed oceanic climate is found along the northern coastline, while certain areas of Beja district in the far south experience a semi-arid or steppe climate (BSk), according to the Köppen-Geiger Climate Classification. As one of Europe's warmest countries, mainland Portugal has an annual average temperature ranging from 8–12 °C (46.4–53.6 °F) in the mountainous northern interior to 16–19 °C (60.8–66.2 °F) in the south and along the Guadiana river basin. The Algarve, divided from the Alentejo region by mountains rising up to 900 meters (3,000 feet) at Alto de Fóia, shares a climate akin to southern Spain's coastal areas or Southwest Australia.

data.text: The archipelagos of the Azores and Madeira both experience a subtropical climate; however, variations between islands complicate weather predictions due to their rugged topography. According to the Portuguese Meteorological Institute, these regions have a relatively narrow temperature range, with annual average temperatures along the coast exceeding 20 °C (68 °F). While some islands in the Azores have drier summer months, the islands are classified under different climate types based on the Köppen-Geiger system. The Azores are identified as having a Mediterranean climate (types Csa and Csb), while islands like Flores and Corvo are categorized as Maritime Temperate (Cfb) and Humid Subtropical (Cfa), respectively.

data.text:
Although humans have inhabited Portugal for millennia, remnants of the original vegetation persist. In Gerês, both deciduous and coniferous forests thrive, while a rare mature Mediterranean forest remains in parts of Arrábida Mountain. The largest continuous subtropical laurissilva forest, dating from the Tertiary period, is found on Madeira's main island. Due to declining human populations and rural exodus, Pyrenean oak and other native trees are reclaiming abandoned lands. Over recent decades, species like boar, Iberian red deer, roe deer, and Iberian wild goat have significantly expanded their range; boars even roam urban areas such as Setúbal at night.

Portugal's protected areas include one national park (Parque Nacional), 12 natural parks (Parque Natural), nine natural reserves (Reserva Natural), five natural monuments (Monumento Natural), and seven protected landscapes (Paisagem Protegida). Notable among these are the Parque Nacional da Peneda-Gerês, the Parque Natural da Serra da Estrela, and the Paul d'Arzila.

data.text: Laurisilva represents a distinctive subtropical rainforest found in limited regions worldwide, notably in the Azores and particularly on Madeira Island, where extensive forests of endemic Laurisilva are protected as natural heritage preserves. These forests host diverse mammalian species such as foxes, badgers, Iberian lynxes, Iberian wolves, wild goats (Capra pyrenaica), wildcats (Felis silvestris), hares, weasels, polecats, chameleons, mongooses, civets, and potentially brown bears [citation needed], observed near Rio Minho close to Peneda-Gerês. Additionally, Portugal serves as a critical migratory stopover for birds, with significant numbers crossing from Europe to Africa in autumn or returning in spring, notably at Cape St. Vincent and the Monchique mountains.

data.text: The region hosts over 100 freshwater fish species, ranging from the giant European catfish found in the Tagus International Natural Park to smaller, endemic species inhabiting isolated lakes, particularly along the western part of the country. Several of these unique and specialized species face high endangerment due to habitat destruction, pollution, and drought. The upwelling off Portugal's west coast enriches the marine environment with nutrients, supporting a diverse array of marine fish; Portuguese waters are among the most bountiful globally. Common marine species include thousands of varieties such as sardines (Sardina pilchardus), tuna, and Atlantic mackerel. Additionally, bioluminescent species, exhibiting various colors and forms like glowing plankton observable on some beaches, thrive in these waters.

data.text: The President of the Republic serves as Portugal's Head of State, elected for a five-year term through direct universal suffrage. In addition to this role, the President exercises supervisory and reserve powers, often likened to the "moderator power" once held by the King during Portugal's Constitutional Monarchy. Presidential responsibilities include appointing the Prime Minister and other government members, considering legislative election outcomes; dismissing the Prime Minister; dissolving the Assembly of the Republic for early elections; vetoing legislation, which can be overridden by a supermajority in the Assembly; and declaring war or siege states. Furthermore, the President is the Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces ex officio.

The primary policing bodies include the Guarda Nacional Republicana (GNR) or National Republican Guard, functioning as a gendarmerie; the Polícia de Segurança Pública (PSP), which is a civilian police force active in urban areas; and the Polícia Judiciária (PJ), a specialized agency for criminal investigations under the supervision of the Public Ministry.
data.label: qwen_2

data.text: Portugal is renowned for having some of the most permissive laws on drug possession in the Western world. In 2001, it decriminalized the possession of nearly all drugs still illegal elsewhere, including cannabis, cocaine, heroin, and LSD. While personal use remains legal, trafficking or possessing more than a ten-day supply can result in imprisonment and fines. Individuals caught with small quantities are offered treatment at rehabilitation centers but can opt out without penalty. Despite initial concerns from other European countries about rising drug consumption, overall usage has decreased along with a significant reduction in HIV infection cases—by 50% by 2009. Drug use among 16- to 18-year-olds has fallen, although marijuana use in this age group saw only a minor increase.

data.text:
From an administrative perspective, Portugal is segmented into 308 municipalities (Portuguese: municípios or concelhos), which were restructured in 2013 to include 3,092 civil parishes (Portuguese: freguesia). In practice, only the municipality and civil parish, along with the national government, are recognized as official local administrative units by Portugal's government. Cities, towns, or villages do not hold legal status, though they may be used for service provision areas.

For statistical purposes, the Portuguese government also uses NUTS classifications, inter-municipal communities, and informally recognizes the district system, which is being phased out following European integration. Mainland Portugal (Portuguese: Portugal Continental) consists of 18 districts, while the Azores and Madeira archipelagos are autonomous regions. Since 1976, the largest administrative units have been mainland Portugal and its autonomous regions.

data.text: The armed forces consist of three branches: the Navy, Army, and Air Force. Their primary role is to act as a self-defense force, tasked with safeguarding the nation's territorial integrity and offering humanitarian aid and security both domestically and internationally. As of 2008, these branches comprised 39,200 active personnel, including 7,500 women. In 2009, Portugal spent $5.2 billion on military expenditures, accounting for 2.1% of its GDP. The practice of mandatory conscription was discontinued in 2004, with the minimum age for voluntary enlistment set at 18 years.

data.text: The Army consists of approximately 21,000 members and is organized into three brigades along with smaller units. It includes an infantry brigade primarily equipped with Pandur II APCs, a mechanized brigade featuring Leopard 2 A6 tanks and M113 APCs, and a Rapid Reaction Brigade comprised of paratroopers, commandos, and rangers. The Navy, with a total strength of 10,700 personnel including 1,580 marines, operates five frigates, seven corvettes, two submarines, and 28 patrol and auxiliary vessels. The Air Force comprises 7,500 personnel and utilizes Lockheed F-16 Fighting Falcons and Dassault/Dornier Alpha Jets as its primary combat aircraft.

data.text: During the 20th century, Portugal was involved in two significant conflicts: World War I and the Portuguese Colonial War from 1961 to 1974. Following the dissolution of the Portuguese Empire in 1975, the Portuguese Armed Forces have taken part in peacekeeping missions in regions such as East Timor, Bosnia, Kosovo, Afghanistan, Somalia, Iraq (Nasiriyah), and Lebanon. Additionally, Portugal has conducted independent military operations abroad, exemplified by interventions in Angola in 1992 and Guinea-Bissau in 1998. The primary goals of these operations were to safeguard and evacuate Portuguese and foreign nationals endangered by local civil conflicts.

data.text: Following the bailout announcement, the Portuguese government led by Pedro Passos Coelho successfully enacted measures aimed at improving the State's financial health. These included tax increases, freezing wages below a certain level in the civil service, and reducing higher salaries by 14.3%, alongside additional governmental spending cuts. Furthermore, the government consented to relinquish its golden share in Portugal Telecom, thereby forfeiting veto power over crucial decisions. By 2012, public servants had experienced an average salary reduction of 20% from their 2010 baseline, with those earning more than €1,500 per month facing cuts up to 25%.

data.text: A January 2011 report by Diário de Notícias, published in Portugal by Gradiva, revealed that from the Carnation Revolution in 1974 to 2010, democratic Portuguese Republic governments fostered excessive spending and investment bubbles through ambiguous public-private partnerships and funding of numerous inefficient external consultancies and advisory committees. This led to significant delays in state-managed public projects and inflated bonuses and salaries for senior management. Continuous recruitment policies resulted in an increase in redundant public servants. Over four decades, there was mismanagement of risky credit, public debt creation, and European structural and cohesion funds.

data.text: Following the 2007–08 financial crisis, it was revealed between 2008 and 2009 that two Portuguese banks—Banco Português de Negócios (BPN) and Banco Privado Português (BPP)—had been accruing losses over several years due to poor investments, embezzlement, and accounting fraud. The situation at BPN was particularly grave given its substantial size, market share, and the political ramifications involved. Portugal's then-President Cavaco Silva, along with some of his allies, had personal and business ties with the bank and its CEO, who was later charged and arrested for fraud among other offenses. To avert a potential severe financial crisis in Portugal’s economy, the government opted to provide these banks with a bailout, which ultimately resulted in future losses borne by taxpayers and the general populace.

data.text: The euro (€) serves as Portugal's currency, having succeeded the Portuguese Escudo. As one of the founding members of the eurozone, Portugal plays a significant role in this economic union. The Banco de Portugal acts as its central bank and is an essential component of the European System of Central Banks. Industries, businesses, and financial institutions are predominantly located in the metropolitan regions of Lisbon and Porto, with Setúbal, Aveiro, Braga, Coimbra, and Leiria being major economic hubs outside these cities. According to the World Travel Awards, Portugal was recognized as Europe's Leading Golf Destination for both 2012 and 2013.

data.text: Since the Carnation Revolution of 1974, which marked the conclusion of a significant period of economic growth in Portugal that began in the 1960s, there has been a notable shift in the nation’s annual economic growth rates.[citation needed] Following the upheaval of the 1974 revolution and the PREC era, Portugal endeavored to align itself with an evolving global economy—a process still ongoing as of 2013. Since the 1990s, Portugal has gradually transitioned from a public consumption-driven economic model to one emphasizing exports, private investment, and high-tech sector development. As a result, business services have surpassed traditional industries such as textiles, clothing, footwear, cork (where Portugal leads globally), wood products, and beverages.

data.text: During the second decade of the 21st century, Portugal experienced its most severe recession since the 1970s, necessitating a bailout from the European Commission, European Central Bank, and International Monetary Fund. The agreement in 2011 provided funding support of €78 billion contingent upon implementing various austerity measures. By May 2014, Portugal had successfully exited the bailout while pledging to sustain its reform efforts. Although the economy contracted by 0.7% in early 2014, unemployment rates decreased to 15.3 percent, despite remaining high.

data.text: Portugal has traditionally been recognized as a sea-power with a robust history in the fishing industry. It is noted for having one of the highest rates of fish consumption per capita globally. The principal landing sites across Portugal, including the Azores and Madeira, based on annual total landings by weight, are harbors such as Matosinhos, Peniche, Olhão, Sesimbra, Figueira da Foz, Sines, Portimão, and Madeira. Processed fish products from Portugal are exported by various companies under multiple brands and trademarks, including Ramirez (the oldest continuously operating canned fish producer worldwide), Bom Petisco, Nero, Combate, Comur, General, Líder, Manná, Murtosa, Pescador, Pitéu, Tenório, Torreira, and Vasco da Gama.

data.text: Portugal stands out as a major producer of minerals within Europe and is recognized as one of its top copper producers. Additionally, it is a significant producer of tin, tungsten, and uranium. However, Portugal lacks the capacity for hydrocarbon exploration and aluminum production, which has constrained the growth of its mining and metallurgy sectors. Despite possessing extensive reserves of iron and coal—primarily located in the north—the country experienced a decline in mineral extraction activities due to low competitiveness following the 1974 revolution and subsequent economic globalization. The Panasqueira and Neves-Corvo mines are among Portugal's most renowned operational mines.

data.text: In April 2007, The Economist examined the underperformance of the Portuguese economy, labeling it as "a new sick man of Europe." Between 2002 and 2007, unemployment rose by 65%, with numbers increasing from 270,500 to 448,600 unemployed citizens. By early December 2009, the unemployment rate had climbed to a record high of 10.2% in over two decades. In December 2009, Standard & Poor's downgraded Portugal’s long-term credit rating from "stable" to "negative," citing concerns about structural economic weaknesses and poor competitiveness that would impede growth and hinder efforts to improve public finances and reduce debt. Furthermore, Moody's reduced its long-term credit assessment of Portugal in July 2011, following a warning issued in March 2011 regarding an escalating risk of default.

In December 2009, Standard & Poor's downgraded Portugal’s long-term credit rating from "stable" to "negative," citing structural economic weaknesses and poor competitiveness that would hinder growth and impede efforts to improve public finances and reduce debt. data.text: Popular tourist destinations in Portugal include Lisbon, Algarve, Madeira, Porto, and Coimbra. The Portuguese government actively promotes and develops new tourist spots such as Douro Valley, Porto Santo Island, and Alentejo. Lisbon ranks as Europe’s 16th most visited city, drawing seven million tourists to its hotels in 2006—an 11.8% increase from the prior year—and has recently overtaken the Algarve as Portugal's top tourist region. data.text: By the early 1970s, Portugal's rapid economic growth, marked by increased consumption and car purchases, highlighted the need for transportation improvements. In the 1990s, following its entry into the European Economic Community, the nation expanded its motorway network significantly. Currently, Portugal boasts a road system comprising 68,732 km (42,708 mi), with nearly 3,000 km (1,864 mi) integrated into 44 motorways. The inaugural motorway opened in 1944, connecting Lisbon to the National Stadium and making Portugal one of the first countries globally to develop such infrastructure, later evolving into the A5 highway from Lisbon to Cascais. While additional sections emerged around 1960 and 1970, it wasn't until the early 1980s that large-scale motorway construction commenced. In 1972, Brisa was established as a concessionaire managing many regional motorways. Many highways require toll payments via systems like Via Verde. The Vasco da Gama Bridge holds the title of Europe's longest bridge.

data.text: Portugal's mainland territory spans 89,015 km² (34,369 sq mi) and is served by four major international airports located near Lisbon, Porto, Faro, and Beja. Due to its strategic location, Lisbon often functions as a hub for numerous foreign airlines at various national airports. TAP Portugal serves as the primary flag carrier, though several other domestic airlines operate both within and outside the country. Although plans were made by the government to construct a new airport near Alcochete to replace Lisbon Portela Airport, these efforts have been delayed due to economic constraints. Presently, key airports include those in Lisbon, Porto, Faro, Funchal (Madeira), and Ponta Delgada (Azores), all managed by ANA – Aeroportos de Portugal, the national airport authority group.

data.text: Comboios de Portugal oversees a national railway system that spans across the country and extends into Spain. This rail network facilitates passenger and freight transport along its 2,791 km (1,734 mi) of operational tracks, with 1,430 km (889 mi) electrified and approximately 900 km (559 mi) capable of speeds exceeding 120 km/h (75 mph). While REFER manages the railway infrastructure, Comboios de Portugal handles passenger and freight services. Both entities operate as public companies. data.text: In Portugal, scientific and technological research is primarily carried out by a network of R&D units associated with public universities and state-controlled autonomous institutions, such as INETI (Instituto Nacional de Engenharia, Tecnologia e Inovação) and INRB (Instituto Nacional dos Recursos Biológicos). The funding and oversight of this research infrastructure are mainly overseen by the Ministry of Science, Technology and Higher Education (MCTES), along with its Fundação para a Ciência e Tecnologia (FCT). Notable R&D units within public universities, recognized for their substantial research grants and peer-reviewed publications in biosciences, include the Instituto de Medicina Molecular, the Centre for Neuroscience and Cell Biology, IPATIMUP, the Instituto de Biologia Molecular e Celular, and the Abel Salazar Biomedical Sciences Institute.

data.text: Portugal boasts significant resources of wind and river power, which are among the most economically viable renewable sources. Since the dawn of the 21st century, there has been a concerted effort to develop a renewable resource industry while simultaneously reducing both consumption and reliance on fossil fuels. In 2006, the Moura Photovoltaic Power Station, then the world's largest solar power plant, commenced operations near Moura in the south. Additionally, the Aguçadoura Wave Farm, recognized as the first commercial wave power farm globally, opened in the Norte region in 2008. By the end of 2006, coal and fuel power plants contributed to 66% of the nation's electricity production, while hydroelectric dams accounted for 29%, and wind energy provided 6%.

data.text: Portugal's national energy transmission company, Redes Energéticas Nacionais (REN), employs advanced modeling to forecast weather patterns and wind conditions, along with computer programs to estimate energy output from various renewable sources. Historically, before the rise of solar and wind technologies, Portugal relied on hydropower plants for electricity generation for many years. Innovative programs now integrate wind and water systems: during nighttime, when winds are strongest, wind-driven turbines pump water uphill; subsequently, by day, the stored water is released downhill to produce electricity, aligning with peak consumer demand. Additionally, Portugal's electrical distribution network has evolved into a bidirectional system, not only delivering power but also sourcing energy from even the smallest producers like rooftop solar panels. The government actively promoted this participation by offering premium prices for those purchasing solar-generated electricity from rooftops.

data.text: According to Statistics Portugal (Portuguese: INE - Instituto Nacional de Estatística), the 2011 census estimated the population at 10,562,178, with females comprising 52% and males 48%. Historically, this population has been quite homogeneous, largely due to a unified religion (Catholicism) and language. This unity was further solidified after the expulsion of Moors and Jews, although many remained in Portugal by converting to Catholicism. These converts were known as Mouriscos (former Muslims) and Cristãos Novos (New Christians or former Jews), with some secretly continuing rabbinic Judaism practices, similar to the secret Jews of Belmonte who now openly observe their faith. The distinction between Old and New Christians was abolished by decree in 1772. Notable Portuguese New Christians include the mathematician Pedro Nunes and the physician and naturalist Garcia de Orta.

data.text: According to Statistics Portugal (Portuguese: INE - Instituto Nacional de Estatística), the 2011 census recorded a population of 10,562,178, with females making up 52% and males accounting for 48%. Historically, this population has been relatively homogeneous, largely due to a shared religion (Catholicism) and language. This homogeneity was reinforced following the expulsion of Moors and Jews; however, many remained in Portugal by converting to Catholicism. These converts were referred to as Mouriscos (former Muslims) and Cristãos Novos (New Christians or former Jews), with some practicing rabbinic Judaism secretly, akin to the covert Jews of Belmonte who now publicly follow their faith. The distinction between Old and New Christians was abolished by decree in 1772. Noteworthy Portuguese New Christians include mathematician Pedro Nunes and physician and naturalist Garcia de Orta.

data.text: According to Statistics Portugal (INE - Instituto Nacional de Estatística), the 2011 census reported a population of 10,562,178, with females constituting 52% and males representing 48%. Historically, this population has exhibited relative homogeneity, primarily due to shared Catholicism and language. This uniformity was further solidified after the expulsion of Moors and Jews, although many stayed in Portugal by converting to Catholicism. These converts were known as Mouriscos (former Muslims) and Cristãos Novos (New Christians or former Jews), with some secretly practicing rabbinic Judaism, similar to the covert Jews of Belmonte who now openly follow their faith. The differentiation between Old and New Christians was officially eliminated by decree in 1772. Notable Portuguese New Christians include mathematician Pedro Nunes and physician and naturalist Garcia de Orta.

data.text: The primary demographic influence in contemporary Portugal appears to stem from its earliest settlers; analysis of Y-chromosome and mtDNA data indicates that the Portuguese descend from Paleolithic peoples who arrived on the European continent around 45,000 years ago. Although later migrations have influenced them both genetically and culturally, their principal ancestry remains rooted in these early inhabitants. Genetic research reveals that modern Portuguese populations are not markedly distinct from other European groups.

data.text: Portugal’s colonial legacy remains integral to its national identity, along with its strategic location at Europe's southwestern tip overlooking the Atlantic Ocean. Among the last Western European powers to relinquish overseas territories, Portugal handed over Angola and Mozambique in 1975 and Macau to China by late 1999. This history has led to cultural exchanges and immigration from former colonies for economic or personal reasons. Once a nation of emigration—like many Brazilians tracing Portuguese ancestry—Portugal is now experiencing net immigration, including individuals beyond its past territories in India (until 1961), Africa (until 1975), and East Asia (until 1999). Around 800,000 Portuguese returned home following the independence of African regions in 1975. By 2007, Portugal's population was approximately 10.6 million, with about 332,137 legal immigrants.

data.text: As reported by the 2011 Census, 81.0% of Portugal's population adheres to Roman Catholicism. The nation also has modest communities of Protestants, Latter-day Saints, Muslims, Hindus, Sikhs, Eastern Orthodox Christians, Jehovah’s Witnesses, Baha'is, Buddhists, Jews, and Spiritists. Additionally, influences from African Traditional Religion and Chinese Traditional Religion are evident among many individuals, especially in areas linked to Traditional Chinese Medicine and African Witch Doctors. Approximately 6.8% of the population identified as non-religious, while 8.3% chose not to disclose their religious affiliation.

data.text: Numerous Portuguese holidays, festivals, and traditions originate from or are associated with Christianity. Despite generally amicable and stable relations between the Portuguese state and the Roman Catholic Church since Portugal's early days as a nation, their relative power experienced fluctuations over time. During the 13th and 14th centuries, the church amassed wealth and influence due to its involvement in the reconquest, its strong ties with burgeoning Portuguese nationalism, and its role in establishing Portugal's educational system, including the founding of its first university. As the Portuguese overseas empire expanded, missionaries played significant roles as agents of colonization, contributing notably to education and evangelization across all inhabited continents. The rise of liberal and early republican movements leading up to the establishment of the First Portuguese Republic (1910–26) altered the role and significance of organized religion.

data.text:
Numerous Portuguese holidays, festivals, and traditions have origins or connections with Christianity. Despite generally harmonious relations between Portugal's government and the Roman Catholic Church since its inception as a nation, their respective influences have varied over time. During the 13th and 14th centuries, the church gained wealth and power through participation in the reconquest, its ties to nascent Portuguese nationalism, and by founding educational institutions, including the nation’s first university. As Portugal's overseas empire expanded, missionaries played a crucial role in colonization efforts, significantly advancing education and evangelization across all inhabited continents. The rise of liberal and early republican movements before the First Portuguese Republic (1910–26) transformed the significance and function of organized religion.

data.text: Within the white shield, the five quinas (small blue shields) featuring five white bezants symbolize the five wounds of Christ (Portuguese: Cinco Chagas), famously linked to the "Miracle of Ourique." According to legend, prior to the Battle of Ourique on July 25, 1139, an elder hermit appeared as a divine messenger to Count Afonso Henriques (later King Afonso I). The hermit predicted Afonso's triumph and assured him of God’s protection. He instructed Afonso to leave his camp alone if he heard a chapel bell ring nearby the following night. By doing so, Afonso encountered an apparition of Jesus on the cross. Overjoyed, Afonso received promises from Jesus of future victories and God's intent for Afonso and his lineage to establish an empire that would spread His name to distant lands, thus selecting the Portuguese for significant endeavors.
